The first warm southerly of the year rose off Corio Bay with a taste of steel and lemon, teasing the water into fish-scale brightness and chasing whitecaps around the curve of Eastern Beach. On the pier, boys and grown men tried to pretend that the breeze was colder than it was. A chilly day, mate. Bracing. That old bluff. Heat makes people honest and they didn’t want it yet.

Kip perched on the rail of Cunningham Pier and watched the wind invent itself. He was a small, wiry thing even by sprite standards, the color of eucalyptus bark and salt. The paint from the famous bollards didn’t stain him anymore—he had learned how to tilt his edges, how to let matter pass through him like a harmless ribbon—but he still liked to rest his bare feet on their flat tops and imagine being tall and wooden and heavy, nailed into the earth.

“You going to help or just sit there like a gull?” Tansy called up from the deck of a fishing boat below. She had stuck a cigarette behind one ear and a pencil behind the other and kept grabbing the wrong one.

Kip turned upside down just because he could. He hung by the knees, hair falling in his eyes, and grinned at her. “I’m watching the physics.”

“The physics is a knot in my net. If you want to study that? Come down.”

He dropped, a clean weightless fall that ended with one hand on the boat’s rail and a soundless flick to bring his feet beneath him. The other sprite aboard, a glassy, jittering kid from the Barwon named Jet, widened her eyes until they flashed like a minnow. Humans never saw the drop. They saw a flicker, a man who had always been there.

“Show off,” Tansy said. She was a rivergrass sprite who had chosen to grow into human shape most days because it got her better tips at the café when she needed them, and because wearing boots and a hoodie kept her warm. Her voice had the rasp of winter frogs.

Kip lifted the net and breathed on it. Stray fish scales glowed like moons. Then he lifted again, pulling the threads apart in a peculiar pattern: up-over, under-twist, swap-two. All magic was pattern. All magic was naming the shape of the problem and then making a different one under its feet. His fingertips left a silver damp that sizzled where it touched sun.

Jet watched his hands. “How do you do that thing with the twist?” she blurted. “You can see where the net is going to break, can’t you? Before it happens.”

“I listen,” Kip said. He didn’t move his mouth when he said it, didn’t say it at all, really; he breathed the words into the woven threads and let the net repeat them. “They complain. They’re old. They want to talk about all the fish they’ve held.”

Tansy rolled her eyes. “That is not listening. That is being strange. Hold your own end, Jet. There. You—Kip—where were you last night? You missed the meeting at the old woolstores. Aunt Beryl made a cake the size of a wheel, and when Aunt Beryl bakes cake you come, unless you want to be hexed so your ears ring for a month.”

Kip made a face. “The woolstores make my teeth hurt.”

“Everything makes your teeth hurt,” Tansy said. “Moonlight on water, the taste of metal, somebody playing bagpipes three streets away.”

“Bagpipes should make everyone’s teeth hurt,” Kip said without heat. “I was down by the river. Mending. Practicing.”

“You and your practicing,” Tansy said, but there was fondness in it. “One day you’re going to practice so hard you bend yourself into a knot and no one will be able to tell where your head is. Aunt Beryl says you should save that for when you’re a hundred and have to tie your own beard over your nose.”

Kip made a knot with two fingers and let it pour away like water.

The wind shifted. It came over the old Balmoral Hotel, over the brick warehouses that remembered sheep and grease. Over the silos. It came with a smell.

Kip’s head snapped up. He didn’t move otherwise, not even breath. The smell was not strong. That would come later, if it came at all. This was a ghost of a smell. The idea of it. Old meat wrapped in plastic and left behind a bin, that kind of look-away reek. A hospital drain on a warm day. Not quite there. Not yet.

Tansy kept talking. “Jet, put your finger there. No, further. He—Kip—there is a smell, isn’t there. I can always tell when you’re not listening.”

Jet wrinkled her small pointed nose. “Ugh. That again? Cousin Birdie said she saw a stain under Prince’s Bridge last night. A moving stain.”

Kip swallowed a word that wasn’t for public. “Where?”

“Downriver,” Jet said. “Near the woollen mills. Like an oil slick. But in the air.”

“Have you told Aunt Beryl? The Anchor?”

“Told everyone,” Tansy said. “Everyone tells everyone. That’s the fun. I think it’s made up. Probably a fox again. Or one of those homeless humans who eats out of bins and smells like it. Poor things. Don’t go anxious at it.”

Kip shook his head. Tansy liked explanations you could poke with a stick. This was not one of those. “It doesn’t eat out of bins,” he said, quiet now, too quiet. “It eats fear. It drinks what runs under the streets and it likes to chew on the bruise of a thing that used to be living.”

Jet stared at him. “You’ve seen it?”

Kip thought of the night six months ago when he had set fog along the rocks in a pattern too complicated even for him to like. He had called for something with long fingers and it had come, laughing, because he had made a door and left it open. The taste in the air after had been like a dead bird in summer. He had woken up at Eastern Park with mud in his hair and no blood in his left hand; it drifted for hours, as if it had forgotten how to be flesh.

“I’ve seen its shadow,” he said. “Keep mending. Please.”

Tansy shut her mouth on a dozen questions. She finished the net while Kip held and Jet fussed and the men talked footy behind them, arguing about the Cats with the same old comfortable rumbles. The smell faded. The wind went back to lemon and steel.

Later, when the sun had leaned itself onto the water and started stretching, Kip walked the promenade in a pair of borrowed boots. He liked shoes when he wanted to feel the ground in a dull way. Socks were harder. Socks made him irritable. The bollards watched him go past; their painted eyes didn’t move, but he felt the tacky hum of old attention.

“If you’re sniffing for it,” said a dry voice, “you won’t smell it with ocean on your lip.”

Kip stopped and turned toward a woman sitting on a bench, her hair like iron filings and her skin full of lines, every one of them earned. Humans would have said she was a woman in her seventies with a glint like broken glass. Sprites saw the keels of ships carved into her shoulders, an anchor at the base of her throat like a brand, the iron taste of ballast and the cotton-lanolin stink of wool half a century old. The Anchor did not bother to hide what she was. She never had.

“Good afternoon,” Kip said. He stood straight, because you did that for her. You didn’t slouch when you were pointed at by the history of the bay.

“Don’t good afternoon me,” she said, but she smiled. “You missed cake.”

“I heard,” he said, because he had. Aunt Beryl had made a cake, and the Anchor had probably sat with her big kind hands behind her big cold eyes and eaten twice her share for politeness, then gone down to the water and spat in it for balance. “Sorry.”

“You’ve been practicing,” the Anchor said. “You’ve been practicing where you shouldn’t. Don’t argue. The river told me. It tells me everything. It is indiscreet.”

Kip stared at his boots. The leather had softened around his toes. He wrinkled them, then stilled when the Anchor raised an eyebrow.

“It’s here again,” he said.

“I know,” she said. “They’re calling it Rankin this time, I think. They like to make names. It makes the shapeless feel like you can put it in a bottle and label it. Fools.”

Kip repeated the name silently. Rankin. The word tasted of rusted nails and wet wool. A local name for a not-local thing. “You’ve fought it.”

“Yes,” the Anchor said. She stretched, the bench creaking under her. “We pushed the last one out when they cleaned the drains for the Commonwealth Games. The engineers did it and didn’t even know they had. Now look. Twenty years of plastic, and lazy rain, and men who pour old fat down their sinks. Now look. The city hums with its kind of happiness. Of course it came. Of course. Moss grows in shade. Rot goes where you leave it a corner. Sprite, don’t go alone.”

He nodded. He wanted to say hope is moss too. It grows if you leave it a corner. Silly.

“There are other smart ones,” she said. “Beryl. That boy who listens to screws and thinks he’s old. The stone aunties under the You Yangs. They’ll help. And you. You are too clever for your own bones. Don’t let that be the death of you.”

Kip gave a lopsided smile. “I can be very stupid if that helps.”

The Anchor rapped her knuckles on the bench; the sound was like a hammer on a hull. “It won’t. Go see the bath at Eastern Beach. They say the water curdled when a child waded this morning. They say the child cried and vomited and her father called CHOICES and then forget what he saw. It can do that. It can make your brain go cloudlike. Remember your shape. Keep a thread to your own elbow.”

“I always keep a thread,” he said, and felt in his pocket for the loop of braided seagrass he had kept since he was a child, when Aunt Beryl braided everything and he collected the ends. He kept a thread to his own elbow. He hummed to himself because he always did, and the tune made itself from wave and gull and joke.

“Something has been humming you back lately,” the Anchor said, not unkindly. “Go on.”

He went.

It is a city that leaves things lying around for stories to trip over. Wrecks in the bay. Brick walls half falling down, graffiti that had intelligence and then didn’t. There were still rabbits in gardens. Sun fell through the lattice at the pavilion and made a charade of shadows. People ate chips too fast because of the seagulls and then fed the gulls when they thought nobody was watching. Human ritual.

The gentle steps down into the sea bath were slick with a translucent green that wasn’t quite seaweed and wasn’t really not. Kip put his bare feet down, one after the other, held the rail, went slow. He could walk on water. That wasn’t the point. There were better respects than that.

Una, the human lifeguard with forearms like a history lesson and tattoos of octopuses on both calves, lifted a hand when she recognized him. She did not think he was human. She didn’t think about what he was. She thought about his help when the boy went under last summer and floated back up with his mouth full of congratulations. She thought about that and decided the rest could be sorted.

“It’s not right,” she said, just like that. “It feels like milk that went off three hot days ago and someone keeps pushing it through the tap out there and hoping we don’t notice.”

“It’s not milk,” Kip said. He dipped his fingers into the bath, or rather let the bath dip itself into him. “It wants you to think it’s that. It wants your nose to be ordinary.”

Una rubbed her forearms, then stopped, annoyed at herself for being unsettled. “We had three old ducks complain they could taste beef when they swam. That’s not a thing.”

“Everything is someone’s thing,” Kip said absently. He had the shape of it, now. He could taste the thin membranes between what the water remembered and what the water had to do. The bath remembered babies who had learned to float here, men who had taught themselves to breathe that way again, women who had come with the softest smiles and no one who would not let them swim in the ocean and had sunk and risen, sunk and risen, slowly, on a rope.

“What are you doing? Is that safe?” Una asked.

“Nothing is safe,” Kip said. “Listen with me.”

Una snorted. “It’s your head. Try not to blow up.”

He closed his eyes and put both hands on the surface, pressing down until the skin of the water curved and held him like a drum. The song he used was old and silly—when Aunt Beryl taught him it, she had used it to make the washing up go faster—but it had a good beat and a sideways joke in it that slid under sorrow and lifted it up. He hummed, and the bath shivered, and his breath came back with a taste like pennies.

Something pushed into him, friendly as a cat, and something else tugged at his hair with childish cruelty. He let it. A kite tried to fly out of his shoulder blade and he anchored it with a thought. The smell rose with the first bright ring of song, bright and then not. It should have dissipated in the wind, should have run out into the bay and gone thin. But a curl of it stuck low over the water, clinging.

He had a moment’s double vision: the bath and his breath and the rail and also a black tube that carried night, not water. The rail became a rib, the steps became teeth, Una turned her head and the tattoo on her calf unspooled into label, expense, glue.

He blinked and the weirdness snapped back into its box. He knew that box. It was not supposed to open on its own.

“It likes to hide in corners,” he said, and his voice wasn’t quite as even as he hoped. He pulled his hands up and water came with them for an extra heartbeat, clinging like a skin that didn’t want to be left behind. He made a little circle in the air with his finger and the piece that stuck broke down, fell in a rush.

Una watched the wet trickle down into the bath. “Are you all right?”

“Fine,” he said, which was the oldest lie in any language. “Where did the child get sick?”

Una pointed. He walked that way, ankle deep, turned three times in a row, once slowly, and sang a different kind of nothing. Luck is not a joke but you can tell it as one. The smell, such as it had been, cast up again, thin as paper. He touched it with one careful knuckle.

“Hello,” he said. “Do you want to be a story that stops here or keeps going?”

A bump, childish-emphatic. Keeps. Goes.

He tried a trick Aunt Beryl hated. He made himself small inside his own head, very small, a single curled-finger sized thing, and sent that thing out through his hand into the smell. It slid under him with ease. It felt like grease with sand in it. It felt like chewing for too long. For an instant he knew the joy of rot, the relief it carried: end of responsibility, end of shape, end of needing to hold anything together. He wanted it. A little.

He cut the wanting off with a hard sharp thought, the kind that had saved him, more than once, from being a puddle of someone else’s idea. He withdrew; the bit of him that had gone out came back with salt all over it that hadn’t been there, and he had to sneeze. Seven times.

Una, who had seen stranger things, pretended not to be alarmed. “Bless you. Stop there before the city runs out of polite.”

“It’s gone,” he said, although they both knew that was bravado. “It doesn’t like to be seen. It will leave when you look.”

“You see it?” Una asked.

“I see the space it likes,” Kip said. “I’ll sweep out the corners. You can help by telling everyone it’s nothing. It feeds on fear. It wants us all a little tired.”

Una narrowed her eyes. “People always want me to tell other people things. The trouble with everyone is everyone else.”

He laughed, and the bath let him laugh, and for a minute there were no black tubes in the back of his eyes.

Later, though, back at the breakwater, the smell came again. Stronger. Kip tried to ignore it, tried to be ordinary, to sit on the rocks and watch the ferries and let his mind simple itself. The You Yangs to the west sat like sleeping animals. The bay was very blue. It was late enough that the gulls had given up their aggressive shift and were starting to beg instead.

The wind told a secret: drains. He stood. His boots were waiting on one rock. He left them. He walked past the carousel and past the fish and chip shops, past the small night things that only moved when no one was looking, past a teenager practicing skateboard tricks on the smooth concrete and swearing Monday-words every time he missed. The stormwater grates along the road all had eyes. He knew their names if he wanted to. He had named some of them as a boy: Gerald, Beige, Ow.

Under the bridge the air tasted like time hadn’t noticed humans had invented plastic. He ducked without needing to, slid sideways through a space the size of a letter slot, and walked on into the kind of dark that had weight.

He hadn’t told anyone. He never told anyone when he did this. He would tell them after he had done it; he could make it into a story then and control its edges. Kip walked to the slow music of his own bones and made small lights from the edges of his fingers. The lights called moths that weren’t moths, made of dust and old sentences. He loved them. He stepped lightly. Once he slipped and his toe went into something that dissolved under it. He pulled his foot back and felt memory try to pull him along. He kept his thread at his elbow. He touched the loop of braided seagrass in his pocket and spoke a nonsense to it: stay. stay. stay with me. don’t do that thing. stay.

He heard the smell before he felt it. No, wrong way round. He smelled sound. He tasted a chord that wasn’t music and that bent the hair on his arms backwards so that each hair shouted. There was a voice in it and he recognized the shape of that voice. He froze, not because fear but because recognition, and he wished he could walk backwards in time six breaths and go back to when he didn’t know a thing he was about to know.

“Who’s there?” he asked, because he was conventional in danger.

“You,” said the voice, and it came from everywhere and nowhere, and it was not a whisper and not a shout. It sounded as if a mouth were too full and trying anyway. The smell flared, a bright slick heavy with a sweetness that was not a flavor and not a promise.

“That’s very clever,” Kip said, to keep it light. “We’re all there for ourselves. Philosophically. You sound like a book trying to be heard over traffic.”

Something moved just at the edge of his light and then moved again closer. There was nothing to look at, and then there was too much. Kip’s light showed the glitter of a wrapper, the curve of an old bottle, a thread of hair that might have belonged to a person or to a rope, and underneath it all a deepen in the air as if it were sagging under a weight you couldn’t see. He did not, would not, focus his eyes on the place where it seemed thickest. He’d learned that the hard way with mirror-water. He looked aside.

“Kip,” said the voice. It said his name. It said his name as if it had invented it.

He made his own voice practical because he had to. “Did you make a child sick this morning?”

“Only a little,” said the voice. “Only enough to make them remember that bodies are bodies and that sometimes they fail. Only enough to teach this day to be long. A small lesson. There are worse.”

“There are worse,” he echoed. “Why?”

“Because I was hungry. I woke hungry,” said the voice, as if that were the end of it. It sounded almost affronted that hunger wasn’t sufficient explanation: the complaint of a winter cat.

“Don’t eat children,” Kip said, gentle, slow. “Don’t eat ordinary days. Eat… the bad ends of things.”

“Your days are ordinary?” the voice said, and laughed. The smell went sharper, like the moment before meat goes from safe to risky. “How proud. How wrong. Ordinary is a word for not-me. I am ordinary. Heaps of me in bins. Heaps of me in drains. Heaps of me in all the boats you make and use until you leave them to rot then pretend they were something else first.”

Kip felt his hands get cold. “Who named you?”

“You did,” said the voice. “You smelled me and you hung a word on me, you thought you were a king with a label-maker. You named me Rankin because you wanted to make me as small as a human man who came and went. Names are for hope. So be hopeful. Name me again.”

The lights on his fingertips guttered and surged. He could put out more light. He could blast this tunnel full of brightness so hard it ached. He could, but it would just show him the all of what he wasn’t ready for, and anyway his kind of magic was not throwing. His kind was making. He took his hand off the pocket with the seagrass loop and counted the bones in his left foot instead, toe to ankle, because that was a map of being alive. He listened. The voice came from everywhere because the voice was inside as well as out.

He had heard his voice like this once before and not known it. He had taken something home that night it rained blood-brown mud from the paddocks. It had followed his breath in and had sat under his ribs and he had sung to it because he sang to everything. He had fed it his own tidy anger at careless humans and it had liked the taste so much it had grown teeth, slowly, gently. He had woke with grit on his tongue and thought it was dreams.

“Child,” said the voice, no longer speaking as the drain. “Dummy. Friend. You have been eating me in middle-of-the-night spoonfuls for a season. And now you come here and talk like you’re a river.”

Kip bit the inside of his mouth and tasted iron. “So we know each other.”

“Oh yes,” said the voice, and then it laughed in a different cadence—a sound he had made when Tansy told a rude joke about a kitchen mop and a nun—and the world slid five degrees sideways. He had a flash of how he must look from outside: a small figure in a black tunnel with his own green-white light haloing his fingers and eyes. He had a flash of his face reflected in black water. He also had a flash of not being a he. Of being the smell itself, a rope of air, a burn of acid, a surprised joy. He backed up one step and his heel bumped a bottle; the noise of it clacking along the tunnel was petty and bright and saved him.

“Stop that,” he said. “I didn’t invite you in.”

“You made me,” said the voice, tender like a knife. “You’re the clever little moss that thinks moss has no enemies. Half your tricks are rot turned sideways. You decay what doesn’t do and call it a charm. You ferment water to get rain. You’re not a leaf-and-sun guy, Kip. You’re a compost heap with a grin, and I love you for it. Come closer. Let’s be the same again. It was so cold alone.”

He heard the truth of it. He heard his own truth curved. He knew what he had done, in the smallest, and he had only himself to blame. He closed his eyes because that let him see better. He imagined his cells, all of them, sweetly sprung like kelp when a current lifts it. He let the current be the kind that warmed, not the cold that took fingers. He said the names of his own parts to himself: spleen, lung, brainstem, metatarsal. He said the name of his mother, who had been a blue ghost in the reeds, and his father, who had not been anything like human and had still come with soft gifts. He said the name of Aunt Beryl. Of Tansy. Of the Anchor and her hands that had been warm on his head when he was feverish once in summer. He said the name of stone. The You Yangs. He said Geelong like an oath and like a lullaby and like a rude word.

“Don’t tell me your names,” said the voice, impatient now. “I know them. I own half of them. I wore them when you slept. You don’t remember? Look at your fingers, smart boy.”

He did. In his light, his fingers were clean. Under the nail of his left thumb there was a blackness as if he had caught dirt that wouldn’t wash out. He scraped it with a tooth. The taste was old fat. He gagged and thought about laughing too hard to hide it. He was alone with a shape of himself and wanted to be the person who could sit down and talk.

“This isn’t fair,” he said, which was ridiculous. Nothing was fair. That had never stopped anyone.

“Fair would be nothing eating anything,” said the voice. “Fair would be the ocean taking all at once. Fair is a game they teach in school so everyone can lose the same. Keep your story straight, bright thing. This is hunger and laziness, and you built it into a decent trick. It carried you when you couldn’t sleep. It smelled what you couldn’t. It made itself,”—a pause, almost proud—“me. I am pretty.”

Kip made his light very small. He made it a dot. He held it in his left hand, just above the heart line. He thought of the loop of seagrass again and did not take it out.

“What do you want?” he asked finally. “Beyond food.”

“To be named,” said the voice, and the smell softened, grew florals around edges he hadn’t expected. “To be given a place. A purpose. I don’t want to be the bin behind the chip shop, loved only by gulls. I want to be the hospital drain that took your spit and let you live. I want to be the worm at the heart of a plum but in a poem. I want to be your mouth when you say ugly and mean useful instead.”

He had not been expecting that. He had been expecting it to ask for a little city of its own where it could make people faint in the daylight. He had been expecting it to ask him to leave, or to join, but not like this. He rubbed his thumb and forefinger together until his nails clicked. His chest hurt. He wanted to sleep. He wanted to walk to Tansy and put his head on her shoulder and tell her everything, and also to never have anyone say poor Kip with their eyes.

“You can’t have my hands,” he said.

“I have one thumbnail already,” said the voice, amused. “Keep the rest. I want a name that isn’t a joke. I want not to be hungry. I want the luxury of a fast. Make me a job.”

Kip started to laugh because the demand was so… domestic. A job. He had time, then, to craft what was needed. He shaped a thought as if he were making rope. “Not drains. Not people. Compost, you said that word. Can you turn what would stink into what will feed? Can you make a garden out of waste? Can you be municipal in your horror?”

The smell paused, considered. The tunnel breathed twice. Water dripped from somewhere like a metronome. In the space between one drop and another, a small shape bumped his ankle and he looked down and saw a rat, clean as rain, watching him as if she had brought her children here for a lecture and wanted to see if the pictures would be funny.

“I can,” said the voice. “I can be municipal.”

“So,” Kip said. He lifted his hand. He did take the seagrass loop out then, and wound it twice round his wrist. “Rankin, I name you Rot-Right. I name you Curdle-Towards, Sour-With-Purpose. I name you Worm’s-Hand and Bin-King and Lord of the Compost Heap, which is no insult in my bed. I name you Friend of Kitchens. I name you Hospital-Drain-Clean. I name you Runner of Rivulettes that feed trees. I name you Protector of Children’s Stomachs, and that’s the big one. You don’t get to play the old joke at the shallow end anymore. Do you hear me?”

It did. He knew it did because the smell changed again, where it curled around his tongue. It shifted from wanting everything to wanting one thing well. It smelled like a good garden on a hot day in January when tomatoes burst and someone laughs and says get a bowl, quick.

But he was not a fool. He did not think he had solved everything with a set of pretty names and a ridiculous title. He had set a pattern, that was all. Patterns help. Sometimes the tide is enough to keep them steady. Sometimes a storm comes. He would need help. He should have asked for it already. He would. He would.

“Do you belong to me,” the voice said, sly now, trying the old trick of flipping the edge.

“No,” Kip said. “We belong to the same city. I will tell Aunt Beryl. I will tell the Anchor. We will set you to work. We will feed you, but not like that.”

It shivered. He heard the start of a sulk and, underneath it, what might have been relief. Something inside him relaxed, as if an inn had put its shutters up in a good storm and lit the fire and put out blankets. He almost fell down right there and slept on the wet. He did not.

He turned around and began to walk back towards the light, slow enough to not be a prey animal. He went sideways through the letter-slot gap, stood under the bridge in the half-heart light, and felt the air again as if he had forgotten what it was. The night smelled like river and tea from a man’s thermos and car exhaust and fried potato. He breathed all of it and smiled at all of it and was too tired to do anything with any of it.

“Hey,” said a small voice near his ankle, the rat perhaps, or a child, or a piece of broken bottle that had a talent. “You forgot your shoe.”

He looked down. He had not been wearing shoes.

He went to the café where Tansy worked the evening shift. She made him hot chocolate with chili and a cinnamon stick, because she was an artist. Jet came in later with hair that had been washed too fast and jam on her sleeve. Aunt Beryl called three times and left three progressively more threatening messages about cake.

“You look like you got in a fight with a mop,” Tansy said softly when the café was empty enough for honest talk. “And lost.”

“I talked to it,” Kip said, setting his cup down so gently he wanted to laugh at himself. He had never been unsteady with a cup. He was unsteady now. “I named it a job.”

Tansy put her face in her hands and then took it out and looked as if she wished her hands had some other, larger use. “You what.”

“I made a compost king,” he said. He wanted to say, I made a thing of myself that hungers and hates. He wanted to say, I recognized my own tongue in the tunnel. He didn’t. You can’t say everything at once. The body will not let.

“Is that wise?” Jet asked from behind a muffin. “I mean, I’m only eleven, but if somebody named me a job I didn’t want I’d chew their hat.”

“I asked it,” Kip said. “It wanted a place. I said yes to the part of it that might be useful. I said no to the part that eats kids. I will need help with the no. The Anchor warned me. I didn’t listen fast enough.”

“Everyone says no to kids,” Tansy said, eyes far away. “Until they don’t. Be careful.”

He nodded and finished his chocolate and ate the cinnamon stick because it was better that way, and he liked how wrong it felt. He watched the door swing open and shut and tried not to think of the word he had avoided ever since the tunnel. It sits sideways on the tongue, the idea that the worst thing outside might be the shape of you. He was not there yet. He knew and did not know and hung the knowledge like washing on a line, where it could lift in wind and look like something else until you pulled it down and wore it.

He slept that night in a hollow under a bank of tea-tree near Rippleside. He dreams in odd loops and sometimes they catch him like a hook. Tonight his dreams went like this: a small boy holds a dead starfish and weeps and the smell of it makes him laugh; a girl dives and stays down and stays down and he pulls her up with long slow hands that are not his and he covers her mouth with rot and she lives; Aunt Beryl stirs a pot that is full of worms and sings under her breath, off-key; the Anchor takes the sea in her fist and squeezes it to jelly; Tansy sits at his left shoulder and says, “You.” He woke three times, thirsty, and did not drink. The river gossiped all night.

Morning did not make things simple. He thought it might. It looked as if it might. The light over the You Yangs was pale and deliberate. Early runners ran with their early runner faces; dogs did silly dog things and then looked serious about it. He let the water of the bay touch his ankles and pretended it was a consecration.

He went to Aunt Beryl with a basket of figs he had stolen off a fence and laid them on her table, which was a door on trestles. She looked at his face, not the figs, and said, “Oh, my love,” the way an adult says oh when a child has found out that a magic trick was done with a mirror.

“You made cake,” he said. It seemed the right language.

She cut him a slice so big it made his wrists ache to hold the plate. “You made a friend,” she said. “Or you named your shadow. It’s the same. Don’t look at me. Eat. We’ll unpick it. It’s what we do. We’ll unpick and pick again.”

He did not mean to cry. He did mean to wash his hands before he touched anyone. Aunt Beryl took his hands and held them in her big soft bread-maker’s hands and sniffed his thumb and said, “Ah. I wondered where my missing fat bowl went,” and laughed, big and rude, and he laughed too and the laugh was the best kind, the one that comes with clean air. Afterwards she wrapped his thumb in a sprig of rosemary and told him to go to the Anchor and confess properly, and then to go down to the gardens by the university and see if the kind old bloke there in the broad-brim hat—the one who actually listened to earth—would want help composting. “Feed your pet,” she said. “Don’t starve it. That will only make it eat you.”

“It is not a pet,” he said, automatically, gently stubborn.

“No,” she agreed. “It isn’t. It’s a pocket in your jacket that you forgot was there. It will hold whatever you put into it until one day you put your hand in and a mouse jumps out and runs up your sleeve. Mind you don’t throw the jacket into a fire with it on. That is to say: don’t panic. The city makes more of this than you do.” She kissed his head and shoved cake at him and he went back out into the bright day feeling stained and again.

At the garden, the old man with the broad-brim hat turned out to be a woman with severe glasses and a bright pink shirt that said For The Love Of Worms. She had badges on her hat: save our soils; kiss me I’m carbon. He loved her immediately.

“I need a job for a smell,” he said, which is not how normal people begin conversations, and she blinked and said, “Me too, mate,” and then laughed when he looked startled and explained about the new worm farm they were trying to keep from being raided by rats. He said he knew a rat who respected fences. She made him tea and told him to hold the bucket while she turned the pile and he held it and breathed and let what needed to feed feed.

It was early yet. There were weeks in it. Months. Years, perhaps. He was a patient person when he remembered to be. He was also a ferocious one when he forgot. The city went on. The bay breathed. Someone lit a fire in a backyard and leaned back smug and then panicked when the wind caught it, and somewhere further down the coast the skeletons of horses that had not outrun flame once upon a time reminded the grass how to be kind.

In the afternoon he went back to the drains with a string bag full of eggshells and coffee grounds and orange peels and left them like offerings in corners that wanted magic. He did it with the careful loving pettiness of grudge work. He did not say a word. He hummed. The smell came and went like a neighbor in a yard, arms folded on the fence.

He was not at the café that evening. He was in a place he did not remember going to, a room with low ceilings and a carpet like teeth, and a man with a suit who said something about community engagement. Kip stared at his own reflection in a framed certificate and the glass swam until all he saw was the black shine of a drain, and then he saw his own mouth open and say, clear as day, “We are going to take what is rotting and fix it,” and for an instant he did not know whether his voice had said it as him or as the thing inside that was him but other. The men in suits nodded as if he had made sense. Maybe he had. For once.

He went home with flyers about waste management and the knowledge that he had signed up for an open day in three weeks where he had promised to do a demonstration. He dreamt a wheelbarrow full of rinds. He woke laughing.

The smell came again, of course. It came size-shift, mood-shift, hunger-shift. It came with music from a party two streets over and it came with the sweat of a man who ran. He was getting used to it. He was getting not used to it. Both.

He heard a child say to her mother, that looks like a fairy, and the mother say don’t be ridiculous and then apologize to the child when the sky changed color for no reason; he did not have anything to do with it. He did and he didn’t.

It kept saying his name. Only sometimes. Only when it mattered. Always in that half-laugh. He was a clever boy. He was a mess. He was Geelong’s oddest son, and he could feel the old city under the new city, the bones under the skin, the drains under the roads, the old docks under the new bars. He belonged to that. He always had. He had never been only one name. He carried the stink and the shine.

He would tell the Anchor the true version. He would. He would tell her he had made a shadow and made it a job and sat in the dark and spoke to himself in two voices and been afraid and loved how good he was at it. He would tell her he had never wanted to be ordinary. He would ask if she could show him how to tie his own beard over his nose when he was a hundred. He would ask to be told no, properly, often.

He walked the bay. He watched the wind build itself again out of nothing. He held his breath. He let it go. He grinned at a gull who was too smart for god and was in the middle of distracting a dog from a hot chip. He wanted to learn that trick. He wanted to be the dog. He wanted to be everything.

“I’m not done,” the smell said, very polite, at his shoulder. “We are not done.”

“I know,” Kip said. “Good. Help me wash.” He stepped into the bath at Eastern Beach again and this time the water held him like an auntie and let him sink a little and then a little more until he could hear the voices of the tiles. He found the place where the child had swayed and got sick and he put his hands on it like a benediction and said to no one and to everyone and to himself, “We don’t eat that. We step around that. There are rules.”

He felt the agreement like rain. He felt disagreement like someone tearing a paper in another room. When he came up for air, Una tossed him a towel and said, “We’re getting a sign made that says no vomit,” and he said, “Make it in Comic Sans if you want people to laugh,” and she said, “You are very specific,” and he said, “It’s the job,” and that was that.

At dusk, Aunt Beryl called again and said bring your thumbs to me and he did, and she trimmed his nails with scissors that had belonged to her mother and sang while she did it and then tucked the clippings into a jar and said, “For later,” and when he looked as if he had a question, she added, “No, I won’t tell you when. Don’t go making it a day. Let it surprise you.”

He walked home through a city that knew him by three names. He let it. He had room under his ribs for one more laugh. He had room for a smell and a song. He had room for the worst sort of kindness, the kind that fixes, that takes away what you thought was going to make you special and replaces it with a job. He had always wanted a job. He had wanted magic. He had both.

He slept and did not dream of drains.

For one night. Only one.

Morning found him with sand in his hair and a taste like cold pennies behind his teeth. He stretched until his ribs clicked into one another in a satisfying way and lay still for one selfish minute, long enough to listen to the small things: water pushing its little shoulders against shore, wind rehearsing on a blade of grass, a beetle attempting a complicated maneuver on a twig and swearing in beetle. Then he got up and did the dull human business of wearing boots and pulling on a jacket as armor against attention, and went to find the woman who kept the bay stuck to its edges.

The Anchor met him two benches along from yesterday as if she had not moved in the dark, as if daylight merely lit the figure she always was. She had knitting today, a brutal-looking garment the color of stormwater with little knots in it like barnacles and needles that gleamed when they caught the sun. Humans looked at her and saw their grandmother or a threat, depending on how they had behaved with boats. Sprites saw a shipwright’s patience, a ledger’s sin-eater, and an iron ring where a headland might be. When Kip stopped, she did not make him speak at once; she looked at his hands, at the line of his mouth, at the bit of rosemary Aunt Beryl had tied on with string and not removed, and she made a thoughtful sound that could have meant anything from poor boy to well, of course.

“I have been an idiot,” he said without preface, because sometimes penance is not a ceremony but a hand out with something that stings on it. He told her about the tunnel in a clean run, words like stones dropped into a bucket. He did not embroider and he did not try to make himself bigger where he had been small. He did not hide that part where he had laughed at rot and felt it as a kindness. He told her the names he had given it and the names it had given itself, and when he said Rot-Right her mouth twitched as if she had caught a fish by its lip and was not yet sure whether to keep it.

“You set it to a wheel,” she said, and the knitting needles went click, click like a bell buoy in a chop. “You gave it a spoke to follow and something to push against. That is not nothing. That is not always the wrong way. Tell me what you did to the child.”

“I gave it rules,” he said, and then he winced at his own pronoun and corrected it because the Anchor had a low tolerance for sloppy thinking. “I gave them rules. I said, no children. It was not a bargain. I didn’t let it be a bargain. It was a naming. I said it out loud to the bath and to the tiles and to Una’s tattoo.”

The Anchor nodded once, a slow weighty thing. “Good,” she said. “Enough? No. A start? Yes. But. You did it alone. You went below alone, and you think very well of your own ability to keep a thread to your elbow, but threads snap on concrete with a little grit. I am going to say a word to you like a teacher with a ruler. Counterweight. You are all air and sideways with a weight in your pocket you think is a stone. It is not. It is a jelly. We will put a stone on the other side.”

“I like stones,” he said mildly, because even now he wanted to make it less sharp. “What kind?”

“Two kinds,” she said, and put the knitting down and looked at him without any humor for a compact span of time. “One you wear. One you ask for. You will wear a ring of iron. Not a pretty thing. Not a story thing. A piece of rail cut with a hacksaw and bent cold. It will make your wrist itch and make people look at you and not see what you want them to see. It will slow the bit of you that runs ahead and opens doors. You will not take it off except to wash your skin under it every third day. If you take it off without telling me why, I will find you and make sure you remember that sometimes keels are people. The other weight is company. You do not go under alone again. You take Tansy or Beryl or the screw-listening boy or Alan who never spells his name the same twice or that glass shimmer of a child, Jet. You take them not to be brave but to be seen. Your kind disappears too easily when it suits you, and I am very, very old and very tired of pulling you back out by your ankle.”

Kip let himself feel the chastening without hiding from it. It made his skin burn in a useful way. He had always thought he preferred to be told no by someone who loved him and could hit hard without missing. “Yes,” he said, because there weren’t other words of value. “I’ll wear your ugly ring. I’ll bring a friend. Two friends if I can bribe them with cake.”

“Cake is currency,” the Anchor agreed gravely, and then she smiled, a sudden flash of harbor-light. “I say ugly because I am jealous. I never had a pretty ring. The bay does that to your taste. Go down to the rails at North Wharf and ask Old Trevor to cut you a bit. He’ll make a joke about prison. Let him. He was never in a prison that wasn’t a marriage. Also—” she paused to count stitches, and the interval broke the air neatly into before advice and after advice— “don’t name anything municipal without checking whether City has already named it. They will sue you. They will come with clipboards and ask if you have permission to call a thing that. If you put a hat on a rat and call it Chair, they will take minutes.”

He snorted and felt the weight in his chest lighten imperceptibly. “I have a meeting in three weeks,” he confessed, remembering the carpet like teeth and the phrase community engagement spoken as if it might be a talisman. “I promised to make a presentation. About compost. For worms.”

Her look softened. “Oh, my heart,” she said in gentle mockery. “You stumble into civilian life like a swan into a hardware store. It will be fine. Bring samples. Make old men hold handfuls of good dirt. Bring pictures of children who have green things for lunch because you don’t feed the drains. Make a joke and make it again. People believe what they laugh at twice.”

He nodded and then, because he had held the darkest part back until he had done the tidy parts, he said, “And it said my name like I say my name. It laughed my laugh in a place where you shouldn’t hear that sort of thing. It wants a job and it wants a home. I am both and I am not. I wanted to be kind and clever and instead I feel like I have adopted a nephew I once killed by accident and then brought back as a houseplant.”

The Anchor didn’t flinch. “You are not unique,” she said. “Do not be insulted. Everyone reptiles their shadow at least once if they live long. You have done it in time. The worst are the ones who wait and wait and then discover that the shadow is a city block wide and already married with children. Don’t be frightened of being ordinary in this. You are very good at dressing work in outrageous clothes so that you feel special doing it. That will serve you now. Outrageous clothes are a protection for shy jobs. Dress your Rot as a king of bins until he believes he is a uniform. And when fear comes up at you and wants to be eaten, send it to me. I like my breakfast complicated.”

It was ridiculous to be steady after that. It was also exactly what he was. He let himself be ordinary in the best way, which was to sit with his elders and not argue with their sense. He sat long enough to feel his muscles become the bench’s muscles, long enough for the bay to shift color twice, and when he got up to go she stuck a pin in his jacket like an aunt at a christening. It was a thin strip of steel twisted into the shape of nothing in particular. Humans would say modernist. Sprites felt the relief of a promise when they looked at it, a dinghy tied with a knot that had seen weather. “For your cuff when you get silly,” she said. “That is, always.”

He went north for the iron. North Wharf was a place that hid under its own stories; the tang of rust had become a perfume there, and the old men who stood with their hands in their pockets watching the gulls had faces like the front pages of newspapers left to bleach on dashboards. Old Trevor had eyebrows like nesting materials and salt tattoos that no sailor would ever have admitted to liking. He did not ask why Kip wanted iron; he did not ask anything except whether Kip had brought him something he could tell his wife about to explain the favor. Kip, prepared by a lifetime in this city for that exact question, put a tin of Aunt Beryl’s apricot jam in his hand and said, “Tell her it’s for toast and thanks,” and Trevor cut the rail with a carefulness that would have shamed a surgeon and then hammered it against his own knee until it made a brutal circle.

“You’ll get a rash under that,” Trevor said, cheerful as a storm. “Don’t scratch. Bandage. Rub it with spit. Wash it in vinegar. Keep both your hands. I like your hands. They look like they should be breaking things that need to be broken.”

Kip slid the iron over his wrist and his breath hitched in a way he hadn’t expected, a small skip as if music had changed key. It was ugly. It was perfect. For a wild useless moment he wanted someone to see it and kiss it like it meant they understood something about him. He settled for the itch and the ache that told him he was less likely to step sideways out of his own body like a bored ghost. He thanked Trevor three times in different registers and left before he said something sentimental and got beaten with a newspaper for his trouble.

The day had grown fat around the edges by the time he got to the university gardens with his string bag of kitchen leavings. For The Love Of Worms was there again in her bright pink, her hat now adorned with a laminated map of the composting system and a badge that said ask me about leachate in a font too happy for the word. She took his bag with reverence; she had the worshipper’s eye when it came to banana peels. “We had a possum try to convert last night,” she said, meaning a raid, meaning pest management, and pointed with her chin at a little patch of fence that had been chewed into because a possum had thought the answer to hunger was inside. “They don’t understand about patience.”

“Most of us don’t,” Kip said, and then he saw the rat. She sat on top of the newest heap with her hands folded on her little belly, looking like a grandmother over soup. Beside her was a teenager rat with a torn ear and the restless look of someone who wanted to graffiti his own name on a moving tram. When Kip sketched a greeting in the careful loose language of gutter, the mother rat flattened her ears and skittered two steps closer as if to be polite and also in case there was bread.

“Nobody told me there would be sauces,” she said, because she smelled the orange peels and coffee grounds and eggshells like spices, and Kip bowed with deeper respect than he had used in the carpeted room. “Mrs Ipswich,” she added to save him embarrassment of guessing. “My boy calls himself Knife because of course he does. He does not bite unless asked. Which he is frequently and unreasonably asked. We watch your piles now. It keeps us moral. I told the girls on the bridge to leave your worm beds alone because once I got fat on a pie near the train station and it made me stupid. Carbs are a trap.”

“Mrs Ipswich, I need a set of eyes with whiskers,” Kip said, thinking of corners under roads and places where drains breathed slowly like asthmatics. “I need to know if the smell I am training goes where I tell it and not where it shouldn’t. Will you be my municipal inspector? I can pay in the ends of things and in ensuring that the traps the council sets are sprung closed before the men with boots remember them.”

Mrs Ipswich blinked in that rat way that is skeptical and pleased. “It is always men with boots,” she said, because female rats had made a study of the category and found it wanting. “Yes, bright boy. We will watch. But in return we want a corridor. A safe one. A pipe from here to the river where no one batters us with a shovel. We want our children to learn to swim without being taught by garbage.”

“We can do that,” For The Love Of Worms put in, because she had a heart large enough to include rodents if it meant the compost went undisturbed. “Look, if we re-purpose the old greywater outflow, and we talk to Facilities about putting a grate with a hinge on it, the kids can go in and out like they’re residents. We can write a sign: RATS ONLY. Then if anyone objects I can tell them it’s part of a research project.”

Kip could have kissed them both. He restrained himself and put his silly specificity where it counted, in a small plan that was a big shape. He walked the perimeter, he hummed luck like a joke with its hand over its mouth, he named the path Mrs Ipswich and Knife would use with a little sideways magic that made it look to human eyes like an inconvenience and to rat eyes like a lane in Paris. He left crumbs of his own thinking along it like the pips of a fruit he wasn’t sure about yet. He set the first proper task for Rot-Right without going underground: he stood beside the newest heap, warm as breath, and said as even as he knew how, “Take this heat and make it into soil that says thank you when we step on it. Keep it here. Keep ahead of the flies. No games with tongues that aren’t yours.”

The answer came not as a word but as a change in texture, a little settling as if a hand had smoothed a bedspread and promised to come back with tea. The smell was not sweet, and it was not cruel. It was a working smell, a job. Kip breathed it and felt the ring on his wrist throb once in time with his pulse, and for the first time since the tunnel he did not immediately think about his thumb. He thought about worms with the contentment of a parish priest thinking about his congregation and their silly, earnest sins.

From the gardens he went to find Tansy, not because he could not go under alone—he could now, easily, the iron made it simple to behave—but because he had been told not to and he was a boy who had discovered that sometimes rules are not an affront but a kindness offered across a table. He found her on her smoke break, which was to say she stood near the rubbish bins with her hoodie up and her arms folded and the fake cigarette behind her ear because she had decided to give up again for the fifth time this year. She had a face that would have made a saint shape her behavior; she used it to make teenagers pick up their litter and to convince grown men that there was not a single chip left.

He did not say, I want you because I am frightened of who I am in the dark. He said, “Want to come under the bridge with me and talk to something rude?” and she tipped her head back and groaned because he knew what gifts to bring.

“Let me get my boots,” she said. “And we should bring Jet because she will cry if she hears she was left out, and also because she will complain loudly enough to attract help if we do something truly idiotic. Also Alan. Alan is a good counterweight. He’s all right angles and bolts. I like the way he refuses to use the right wrench out of principle.”

They collected their company like cheese and crackers. Jet turned up with a windcheater that said Swim Team even though she did not swim; she liked uniforms on other people. Alan—or Allen or Allan depending on which hardware store had given him a loyalty card that week—met them with a bag of screws he had been listening to all morning. He looked like a walking toolbox, and he had a worrying habit of falling in love with machines. Kip loved him for the way he steadied the air when he stood in it. He took them to the Prince’s Bridge and then, because he had promised, he did the unglamorous thing of standing still and making sure everyone had a way back out before they went in.

Under the bridge it was damp and complicated. The day’s heat had curled into itself and made a smell like old library and tar. Kip felt the first brush of Rot-Right along his jaw in a greeting that was insolent and domestic at once, and he raised an eyebrow at the air as if disapproving of a cousin with bad jokes. “We brought witnesses,” he said aloud because it mattered. “We brought friends. We brought someone who will hit me if I go sideways.”

“I will,” Tansy said. “I have been practicing open-hand slaps on wallabies who steal sandwiches.”

Jet peered at the darkness and then at Kip, her eyes going minnows again. “It won’t stick to me, will it? I have my school carnival next week and if I vomit on the starting block again I have to go to church.”

“It won’t stick,” Kip said, easy as a lie that happened to be true today, and he felt Rot-Right’s attention flick to Jet and then away, sensing the wrong meal. He moved his fingers through the air in a pattern Aunt Beryl called a grandmother’s weave when she taught him to keep busy hands busy and tied their threads to his own elbow and to the iron and to Tansy’s scowling mouth. “Hello,” he said, as if this were a neighbor’s kitchen and he had brought scones. “We have rules. We have a job. Do you want to meet my friends and not scare them?”

It came like fog does, all at once and also not at all. The smell rose and spread and then settled lower, a polite guest conscious of their own heavy perfume. Alan made a face that suggested he had licked a battery. Tansy breathed through her mouth and glared, which made the smell pull itself in a fraction like a dog told to leave it. Jet stood on one foot and then the other and muttered, “It’s not as big as Birdie said. She said it was like the smell of a fish two buses ago.”

“It changes,” Kip said, and put his hand on the tunnel wall so he could feel the water, its lazy rush. “Rot-Right. This is Tansy. Do not tease her. She will break your nose and you will discover you had one. This is Jet. She is new and thus very precious. You will not bite her. This is Alan. He keeps the metal in this city from sulking. He will tell you to mind your own business with drains. You will obey him because he has a wrench and no tolerance for nonsense.”

There was a sensation like a nod, a lowering of temperature that wasn’t cold but that made the hair stand up on their arms. Alan squared up to the air as if he were at a tradesman convention and said with all the dignity of a man in love with bolts, “That grate on the west side needs a new bracket. Don’t lean on it. I’ll bring a proper one tomorrow. If you eat the bracket, I will come down here with a magnet and retrieve every small piece of you that adheres and use you to attract screws at a market stall.”

“I like him,” Rot-Right said inside Kip’s voice, borrowing his mouth just enough to make the others twitch. Kip surrendered an inch and then took it back. He had promised not to make bargains without asking. He made a show of spitting on his thumb and wiping the wall to break the shape. Tansy did not hit him, but she did flick his ear hard, which was mathematics of a sort.

They walked a slow loop through the section of drain that had been worst the day before. The heavy sense of hunger had thinned in the corners, replaced by a slick little satisfaction, and every time he felt it Kip named it again in his head, softly, like laying out teaspoons: Worm’s-Hand, Bin-King, Sour-With-Purpose. At one bend, where the silt made a shape like an ear listening, they came upon something new: a stain on the stain, a smear of black that did not belong to any story he knew. It smelled not of rot but of solvent, the hateful clean of something that eats paint. Alan went on one knee like a man proposing to a chemical and examined without touching. Tansy swore under her breath in the delicate river language of frogs. Jet said, “Ugh,” like a child at a butcher’s window.

“Not ours,” Alan said in the tone that meant he will call in favors for this. “Industrial. Somebody poured something down the wrong throat. They do that when they think nobody watches.”

“CHOICES?” Jet asked, because the acronym had turned into a game at school, into whispers and dares. “Do we call and ask them to forget it for us?”

“No,” Tansy said with a firmness that made the dark look safer. “CHOICES will forget the wrong bit and leave us with the man who thinks that the best way to clean a stovetop is bleach and fire. We call Aunt Beryl because she knows people with hoses. We tell the Anchor because she knows how to frighten a foreman without moving from her chair. We tell For The Love Of Worms because she will chain herself to a pipe and get on the news.”

Kip felt Rot-Right push away from the black smear, offended, which was a relief and an alarm. He could use offense. He could turn insult into appetite for the right thing. He could also watch it make a new hunger, and there were only so many rules you could tie onto a living idea before it gnawed through boredom. He took a breath and then another, setting his ribs like a net against a hard, slippery pull. “Leave that,” he said aloud for clarity. “Not yours. Not mine. We will get brooms. We will get buckets. We will do this like stupid humans in yellow vests and hats. You can watch and be self-righteous.”

“What a mood,” Tansy murmured, amused despite the sting in her nose. “I like this version of you. It suits the iron.”

They marked the place with chalk and an argument with the stone, which would hold until morning. On the way out, Jet snagged her toes on something bright and picked up a small plastic bracelet that said LiveStrong in the remnant language of a charity that had meant well and then gone sideways. She turned it in her fingers as if expecting it to speak. Kip took it and made a face and then slid it onto the iron as a joke that would either make the universe chuckle or take it personally. It made his wrist look like a child had decorated a prisoner. He liked the dissonance. He made it a promise to remember that good intentions are not armor. He made it an oath with plastic for a seal.

They emerged into late afternoon and the kind of light that makes even ugly buildings look like they have meant to be that way. The smell of hot chips and sunscreen rushed them like lovers who had been waiting for months. On the promenade, Aunt Beryl was pretending to mind her own business and failing; she had a sense for when her people went under rocks. She had a hose in one hand and a bucket in the other and two teenage boys behind her already wearing high-visibility vests that clashed offendly with their aesthetic. “We are going to be stupid humans now,” she said briskly. “I told the council it was a community art project. They said okay because they thought it would keep us busy. If anyone asks, we are painting things that only show up when it rains.”

Tansy kissed her on the cheek and took a vest; Jet pretended to hate hers and then straightened it so that it sat right on her narrow shoulders. Alan hefted a broom like a weapon he had been born to wield, and Mrs Ipswich appeared on the lip of a gutter with four of her girls and six boys, all eyes and whisker, and announced that they would appreciate a break in the gendered labor division and take that far corner. Kip took a breath and then another and felt his bones count themselves.

They worked until their backs spoke fluent complaint. They scrubbed and swept and made jokes of the kind that make work light even when work is mud and chemicals and fear dressed up as seriousness. Aunt Beryl sang a baking song and made it rude; Jet invented harmonies that were wrong on purpose; Alan lectured the drain about respect with the tone of a man who will teach his toaster to regard toast as a vocation. The black smear lightened and then broke, and when the first strip came away there was a smell like rubber promises and Kip had to hold his breath and say his own name twice to not make a door with his mouth and pull the wrong thing in to eat it all in one gulp.

“Hat,” the Anchor said later, when they took their wet vests to the café and hung them outside as if they were flags of an improbable nation. She had turned up without anyone seeing her arrive, as she did. “If you are going to do this thing where you make municipal work look like a sacrament, wear a hat. The sun will steal your sense otherwise, and then I have to hold your ears on when they fall off.”

“I have a hat for worm day,” Kip said, hearing himself sound sixteen and feeling no shame in it. “It has a badge.”

“Of course it has a badge,” she said. “Everything you wear has an opinion.” She plucked at the plastic bracelet on his iron and made a face. “This is tasteless and perfect. I approved of that charity until it turned out the man was a man. Keep it. Let it annoy me.”

They fed themselves like children after sport: chips, battered fish, a noble salad Tansy insisted on that tasted better than it had a right to. The city moved around them in the kindly way some places have when they are pleased with what their people are up to. Kip felt Rot-Right sit at his shoulder like a dog allowed inside for once, head on paws, watching with bright greedy little eyes and refraining from begging because it had been taught that it could not put its nose on the table. He wanted to stroke the air and say good job and that felt like a perversion; he resisted and ate his chips and told Jet to stop putting vinegar on everything because she was making the paper melt.

Night brought new rumors like candy in pockets. Someone sent a message that the underpass near the old tallow works had started to sing. Someone else said a man had taken off his shoes by the botanic gardens lake and walked in and then walked out again and claimed he had seen a horse, which meant old fire had rolled over something and made it a picture. A woman came to the café with a child who had the leftover emptiness of a morning’s sickness behind her eyes, and Una came by and sat for a minute and told Tansy that the bath had a stubborn taste at the shallow end like someone had boiled a kettle in it and then put their hand in and shouted. Kip listened and did the arithmetic that this city makes you do when you love it: how much? how bad? who do we call? what in exchange?

He could have stopped there, made the day his flag, slept the sleep of a person with a ring on their wrist and rules on their tongue. He could, but other appetites in other people don’t obey even the best intentions. Around midnight, too late for a decent soul and too early for a sinner, his phone—a thing he owned both ironically and because a rat queen had insisted—buzzed with a message that had not come down any network he paid for. It was in the shape of scent, which is to say it didn’t show on the screen and it made him swallow before he answered. It said: child, hurry. It said: old fat old fat old fat, which was Rot-Right’s shorthand for trouble in a place where once animals had fed a city and now only ghosts did. He didn’t wake Tansy or call Jet or drag Alan out of bed like a lover with bad timing. He got as far as thinking of their faces and then stopped with his hand on the door because the iron on his wrist had heated to a slow warn. He had promised. He had said he would not go alone. He stood there and let that irritation that always lived at the back of him rise until he could taste its lemon, and then he sent three messages that looked like prayers and were just logistics.

The tallow works had been a stink and a half in their day, a religion of fat. People had once dipped their hands into tallow and rubbed it into leather and hair, had boiled it and made candles, had carted it off in barrels that leaked and made dogs love whatever road it had touched. Now it was brick and memory and signage with sepia photographs of stern men who had never learned to smile without a pipe. The drains underneath had eaten a thousand small deaths and could not be expected to pretend they hadn’t. When Kip and his tired small army went down with torches and buckets and the foolishness that makes citizens out of us, he felt the place rise like a bear out of sleep and had to make himself larger inside to not be taken for an intruder. Tansy had brought a bag of coffee grounds and sacrilege—someone’s leftover gravy in a jar—and Jet had a superstition in her pocket in the shape of a coin that had been run over by a train and come out more patient. Alan had a bolt from a ship that had never found its home and wanted one; he carried it like a dog carries a toy.

It wasn’t the same as before. That mattered. The black solvent-smear glowed in their torchlight in a way that felt wrong, and the smell that rose was not Rot-Right’s humble pantry. It made Kip think of a hospital corridor lit too bright with bleach, and for a moment he swayed and had to find the rail with his hand and hear the iron on his wrist sing. He didn’t so much see as understand that someone had not poured waste in fear or laziness this time. Someone had practiced. The smear sat in the corner like a prank, like a man with a hat pulled low waiting to watch people slip.

“Not accident,” Alan said softly, and if he had not had both hands on his broom he would have found a way to hit something that could be blamed. “Not stupid. This is done with an idea. And it’s the wrong idea.”

Jet edged behind Tansy as if she were smaller and needed the height. “Who would do that?” she asked, genuinely bewildered. “Who would pour poison on purpose where children go to get rid of their fears?”

“People who want to sell something,” Tansy said. “People who make you frightened and then hand you a bottle with a label that says salvation and a price tag that makes your teeth hurt. Or bored men who want to see if they can get in a paper. Or, gods help me, someone like Kip who thinks he can keep a lid on a thing and then forgets that lids are for pots, not ponds.”

“I didn’t,” Kip said, and then, to his own surprise, laughed because she had offered him a mean little gift: the chance to reject guilt that wasn’t his, and he cherished those. “This one doesn’t smell like me. It smells like—” He stopped because he had to chew the idea before it could be words. “It smells like removal. Not decay. It wants things to go away without consequence. It is the opposite of us.”

Rot-Right bristled inside him like a cat when a dog is mentioned. He felt it push itself between him and the smear, not to eat it but to stand there as if insulted by the chemistry. It made a new smell he had not smelled on it before, a bitter pride, and he realized with a start of something like hope that giving anything a job makes it jealous of that job’s dignity. It wanted to be the only sovereign of certain filths. He could use that. He could ride it like a bad pony if he was careful.

“Eat around it,” he said, soft, and Rot-Right rolled its shoulders like a boxer and did what it was told, taking the edges of filth and turning them, taste by taste, into something a worm would smile for. The center stain sulked and did not change. Alan crossed himself in a way that was not church but habit, and Tansy folded her arms so that nobody could see that the tiny hairs on them had lifted.

They set to with buckets and old cloths. They worked like fools. Aunt Beryl arrived with a bottle of vinegar and the stinging voice of someone who once ran a kitchen where men had bled on chopping boards and bragged about it. The Anchor did not come, but the feeling of her did, the sense of a keel under them, and Kip found himself talking to the dark about why drains matter as if he were a teacher and not a boy with too many talents he had not learned to hide. He talked and worked and held his wrist steady when the iron made him want to scratch until he bled. He did not let Rot-Right play with the fear that started slow in Jet’s ribs and built when they found a small dead fish where it should not have been. He paid attention to brick and flow and bolts. He made himself a man doing a job instead of a story trying to write itself.

When they were done, it wasn’t done-done. It was better. It was a promise that someone saw. It was a warning. On the way back to the light, they met a man in a hi-vis vest with a council logo and clipboards for hands. He had the look of someone who had read a policy and married it, and his smile was the kind that had to be practiced. “Evening,” he said. “Community engagement?”

“Yes,” Kip said in a voice that could have been a lie and wasn’t. “We are engaging the community with ourselves as they are too busy to come along. We are going to put up a sign that says we do not pour death here.”

The man looked at their buckets and their black streaked cuffs and Aunt Beryl’s vinegar and Allen’s broom and Jet’s coin and Tansy’s don’t-test-me and he adjusted his expectations on the spot like a belt. “We had a call,” he said, and flicked through papers as if the answer would be printed for him so he wouldn’t have to summon it. “From CHOICES. They said there were reports of a… smell. But that it had been dealt with.”

“CHOICES would tell you we died to save you and then ask for a signature,” Aunt Beryl said with sweet venom. “Help us with the sign. Or get out of the way.”

He got out of the way. After he had, he stood with his clipboard and watched them finish by the light of phones and stubborn, and there was a tiny shift in his spine that said something had moved in him where rules live. He would go home and tell someone who wore a tie that he had seen a thing that worked, and he would take credit, and maybe next time he would bring gloves and not tell his boss.

That night Kip slept without the sea talking in his ear. He slept without drains. He dreamt, briefly, of a worm in a top hat conducted by a rat with a baton. He woke laughing in that helpless way that makes your ribs ache and then found his iron ring pressed a round mark into his skin and itched like truth. He did not take it off. He did not scratch. He rubbed vinegar into it as instructed and thought of Trevor’s grave cheer. Then he went out into a day that had not been made new by his labor and was nevertheless a little brighter in the corners where he had scrubbed.

He forgot, for a precious hour between breakfast and the hour when the sun reminds everyone that their bodies are animals, that he was interesting. He sat in the library and read a pamphlet about municipal waste with serious attention and translated its bureaucrat into person speech in his head. He made notes with a pencil Aunt Beryl had sharpened with a knife. He thought about what he would say at worm day that would make old men put their fingers into a bucket and come up smiling. He wrote ROT RIGHT in big letters and then crossed it out and wrote ROT-RIGHT with a hyphen and then circled it and then put a line through that too because the Anchor would smack his head for trying to brand an idea that wasn’t finished. He frowned at the word leachate so hard that a woman across from him laughed behind her laptop and he looked up and smiled with his mouth like a shy dog.

The city did not leave him that hour as a gift without price. At eleven, his phone sang out with a ringtone he had not set and would not have chosen—bagpipes; the universe is a comedian with poor taste. It was not Aunt Beryl or Tansy or Alan or Mrs Ipswich with gossip. It was a number he didn’t know and a voice he recognized from two meetings ago, a suit voice with friendliness sprayed on. “Kip,” it said, and he could see the man’s shiny shoes and his fear of having his tie pulled by a toddler. “We are so excited about your demonstration. We’ve had a wonderful idea. There’s a developer coming to have a look at the waterfront and we think it would be marvelous if you could do your little show just when he walks past. It will show community spirit. It will show that we are, ah, responsible. It will show that the smell—what smell?—isn’t an issue. You understand.”

The ring on his wrist ate three heartbeats and spat them back out hot. Kip breathed once and then left the library because he did not want to say no under that polite quiet. He walked out into lemon and steel and the taste of expanding day and let himself be his most harmless voice while he sharpened it underneath. “I understand that you want to hire me for free to make a man feel less afraid of something he should be very afraid of if he wants to put his name on it,” he said, kindly. “I understand that you will put my name on a flyer in small letters and then throw it away. I understand that if I say yes this time you will ask and ask until I say no rudely and then you will say community engagement is so hard. I will do my demonstration for the people who bring banana peels in their pockets. If your man is one of those, he is welcome. If not, he can watch me love dirt and be confused.”

There was a little silence. It had paperwork around it. Then the voice said, pleasant in a way that would look like teeth if you could see it, “I don’t think you appreciate—”

“You are correct,” Kip said and hung up because Aunt Beryl had once taught him there is a kind of magic in ending a conversation before the other person has written your line for you. He put his phone in his pocket and let his ears ring in a way that wasn’t a hex but would do. Then he went to the garden and checked on the piles. Then he went to the bath and put his hands in and did nothing except let the tiles tell him who had put their feet there and been afraid and learned not to be. Then he went to the Anchor and sat with her while she knitted enough for someone with hips. They did not talk about anything that needed a name.

Towards evening, he found a child on the promenade staring into the gaps between planks with the seriousness of someone who has lost something important. She had a plait that was too tight and shoes that had been carefully chosen because they flashed when she stepped in a certain way. Her mother was on a bench doing the long deep breathing of a person who is on the edge of the day and of tears and does not have the luxury of either. Kip crouched with his knees making agreeable noises and said, “What is missing?” and the child said, “My fish is in the water,” with the dignity of a person who is already rehearsing loss. He put his face close to the gap and saw a plastic fish with a stupid grin and something else in the water, something that had no grin. He put his fingers down and almost put them into a smell. He did not. He used his light and he used a small shape he had kept since he was too small to do anything but play—hook-and-pull—and he lifted the toy. The child did not smile. She looked at him as if she had expected it to be simple and everything else to be harder. He put the fish in her hand and said, because it was the only vow that mattered, “We don’t eat what you love,” and the water under him agreed so sweetly he could have wept.

He would break his rules soon. He was that kind of creature. He would go down alone because someone’s breath would be running out and because he trusted himself too much and because Rot-Right would laugh like he did and promise. He would do it; he knew it like knowing your own calf muscle in the night. But not today. Today he had an iron ring and a rat queen and a woman in pink who loved worms like they were saints. He had an Anchor who had told him he was ordinary and made it sound like a blessing. He had Aunt Beryl’s cake in a tin on top of a fridge with a note on it that said touch and die and a smaller note under it that said unless you are hungry. He had a smell that now wore a badge that said municipal and a set of knees that made him remember to stand carefully on wet steps.

When he went to sleep, he put the ring on a string and ran the string up to the hook Aunt Beryl had once used to hang herbs to dry. He slept with his hand tangled in it so that if he stirred, it would pull and he would remember there was gravity and that he had agreed. In his dream, a gull stole a hot chip and then brought it back because it had forgotten how to chew and Rot-Right, in a little cap like a stationmaster, showed it how, patiently, cheap and expert at once. In the morning he woke to fingernails against a window and for a long raspberry of a second he was back in the tunnel. He sat up fast enough to pull the string and make the iron knock his wrist and wince and swear, and then he saw the culprit: a boy with a face mostly made of good intentions holding a flyer against the glass. It said WORM DAY in letters that had been written by an optimist and then traced by a pessimist, and under it Aunt Beryl had written in texta bring your stink. He did not know he was laughing until his ribs protested. He dressed. He made a list that included words like signage and buckets and children and Mrs Ipswich and Alan’s bracket. He went to work. He let himself be ridiculous about it. He hummed a song about leachate and decided he did not care if it had too many syllables. He was, for the moment and with an ugly ring telling him a story every time it itched, an honest boy with a job.

The morning opened itself like a door that had been painted too often and stuck, then gave way with a sigh and a flake of old color, and everything behind it smelled of cardboard and grass.
