Kip arrived at the university gardens carrying two buckets of coffee grounds and a bag that clinked with jars because Aunt Beryl believed in samples, publicity, and sugar in equal portions. His hat had a badge on it that declared him an enthusiast of microfauna and the pin the Anchor had stuck in his cuff did not behave like jewelry; it behaved like a nail through a plank and made his sleeve sit different. The iron ring sat on his wrist under the bright yellow of a reused festival wristband that said in wobbly text WORM DAY while the old LiveStrong bracelet took the whole combination very seriously and made grown men smirk and then look away because irony felt risky around someone with a job.

For The Love Of Worms had turned the lawn into a fair that wouldn’t scare a crow, which took skill. There were trestles with laminated signboards articulating the romance of leachate, a kid’s corner with cardboard tubes that allowed small people to emulate an earthworm without suffocation, and three plastic tubs of finished compost with wooden spoons for people to turn and smell so they would remember that the word humus wasn’t a dip but a hymn. Her real name turned out to be Maureen if you caught her hat off, which no one did unless she wanted them to, and she had recruited two science students with hands like puppies to man the stall that sold tiny worm farms in clear boxes so people could pretend to be gods and then discover they didn’t like having that much responsibility. Mrs Ipswich and Knife perched on the edge of a straw bale like judges on a cooking show, washing their whiskers with an air of moral superiority that would have been unbearable in any creature without a tail, and their cousins patrolled the freshly hinged grate that led to the safe corridor like they had been municipal staff all their lives.

Alan had parked himself at the point most likely to be mistaken for structural vulnerability and hung his new bracket from his belt as a talisman while he explained to a boy in a scooter helmet that screws have desires and you can either listen or strip them and live with your shame. Tansy ran the book for swaps, which meant a handwritten list of who had brought banana peels and who had delivered eggshells and who was now owed a baggie of soil in return, and she made sly marks in the corner for those who left their contributions in plastic. Jet wore a high-vis vest that drowned her and had a whistle that she was not allowed to use and therefore could not stop touching. Aunt Beryl stood behind a table that had a sign in texta that read CAKE and had iced three slab cakes with the same word in three different languages because she liked showing off and because if someone complained, she could pretend it was accidental.

The council had lent them bunting in the shape of leaves that made the worm farm look like it was celebrating an election, and someone had convinced a band of local teenagers to play a set of songs about soil that were nearly comprehensible and very sincere. A man from Facilities trudged up with a cone witch’s hat that said wet floor and then, realizing that if he put it on the lawn it would symbolize damp grass, he endured a crisis of ontology that he solved by giving it to Jet and asking her not to wear it, which she immediately did. The day was not hot enough to be cruel and not cold enough to test anyone’s vows; it was a good day with a small shiver running through it like a cat under a table thinking about knocking over a vase.

Kip felt Rot-Right in his ribs and his knees and the skin inside his wrists, present the way warmth is present in bread not long out of an oven, and he had to keep an eye on it the way you keep an eye on children who have just discovered carrying chairs over their heads. He was very good at being ordinary when there was an audience for it, which is to say he had practiced being a version of himself that let other people talk and then talked back in ways that did not scare them. His job today was to take the idea of rot, which most people thought of as failure, and dress it like a success in a suit made of tomatoes and a tie made of the laughter that happens when a person who thinks they hate gardening puts their nose into soil and comes away stunned. He threaded his iron ring around the handle of a shovel for a moment to ground himself, felt it bite, and put it back where it belonged with care that would have looked superstitious if anyone had been watching closely.

The suits arrived later than they said and overprepared, carrying branded water bottles and expressions that had been practiced in mirrors until the wrinkles at the edges of their eyes knew when to do their dance. They came with a developer whose shoes had never met a cow pat and who wore his confidence like sunscreen, thick and shiny and not entirely rubbed in. He had a name that tasted of forest and concrete at once and he said it without offering it, leaving it to be taken from the air, and the council liaison who had tried to book Kip for free vibrated beside him like a small generator powering hope. CHOICES drifted by in the form of a woman with a clipboard and a relaxed jaw; if you put a hand near her the air felt like the moment a burp is swallowed with shame, and she managed to stand in the shade of nothing. Kip saw them, put them in the corner of his pocket where you put a coin you don’t want to spend without forgetting you have it, and went on retrieving banana peels from bags with gratitude like he was being offered diamonds.

He began his talk by not talking. He let quiet sit on the grass for a little while, not long enough for anyone to grow bored, just long enough for the gulls to complain that nothing exciting was happening and go elsewhere. He held up a jar of coffee grounds and a jar of orange peels and a handful of eggshells and the small damp body of a cabbage leaf, and he put them one by one into a clear bin as if he were building a cake that no child would recognize as cake until someone sliced it. Then he reached into the tub of finished compost and pulled up a handful of crumbly black that did not clump and did not stink, and he dusted it across the grass in a gentle arc like salting a story and asked people to come smell it, please, right now, with no dignity, with their whole faces.

There is a trick to making strangers choose to embarrass themselves in a wholesome way, and Kip had been taught it by Aunt Beryl and perfected it in the draught of a city that doesn’t like to be told to pay attention unless it is being offered a free sausage. He took the first few hesitant noses and made them seem brave, he made the laugh that says I’m silly and it’s fine arrive before anyone needed it, and he kept his voice low so people had to lean in and miss nothing. When the first old man made the face and the first child made the gasp and the first woman let her shoulders go in a way that said she had not realized she had been holding them on purpose for years, the thing took itself on like yeast in water, and the crowd ceased to be an audience and became participants in the business of liking rot for the first time in daylight.

He spoke then, and he did not say decay; he said return. He did not say breakdown; he said back to, and he didn’t make metaphors about death even though he could have balanced five without spilling one. He talked about worms as stomachs that make soil who are also mouths, about bacteria as small workers to whom we owe wages paid in peels and leaves and the patient end of lettuce, and he let people hold worms in their palms if they promised to be quiet with their fingers. He asked the children to name three things they would not eat—no children’s tears, no plastic, no chicken bones—and then asked the same children to name three things their worms would love, and he let the answers be wrong until they weren’t. He could feel Rot-Right settling into its municipal jacket like a dog allowed to stay inside on a wet day for the first time and told not to get on the couch, and every time he felt it lean toward a fear for the taste, he nudged it with a thought the way you nudge a steering wheel to keep a car between the lines.

There was a wheelie bin in the shade of a peppercorn that should not have been there because nothing should be where it was, and even if Kip hadn’t noticed it with his eyes, Mrs Ipswich’s whisker-twitch would have drawn a thin red line around it in the air. Knife stood beside it with his bad ear forward and his good ear flat and his eyes narrowed as if listening to a small radio station no one had paid to put on the dial. Jet drifted that way because she had the dangerous talent children have for moving toward trouble while looking like they were taking responsibly for a small plant, and Tansy corrected her path with two fingers like a neat wind. A smell in the bin tried to make itself ordinary and overshot; it arrived as sterilized courage and the memory of dentist rooms, and the Anchor’s pin warmed against Kip’s wrist under the band of words and plastic and iron until he wanted to scratch and had to not.

He did not interrupt his talk about the speed of the worm gut and the dangers of too much citrus in a small system, because panic can be a kind of chemical too. He said, “Everyone rub a little of this”—and he made a cut across his own palm with his voice to give permission—“on your wrists where you can smell it later, and you will think nice things about your grandmother who had a garden even if she didn’t. If you don’t have a grandmother, borrow Aunt Beryl, but bring her back in time for cake.” They did it because people like instructions that give them a story to tell about the odd smear on their skin, and the act of putting dirt where perfume goes lodged a small, ridiculous oath in place: remember. He looked at Maureen and she lifted her eyebrows at the bin without moving her head because she did not want to frighten her worms or her guests, and Kip nodded gently and directed his talk so that his moving body put him between the bin and the most persuadable faces.

The developer made an attempt at sincerity that might have worked in a different town. He held up a worm farm like a prop and talked about circular economies with the rhythm of a man who had memorized the right nouns, and he tried to put a name on what Kip had done that would make it into an asset that could be toured like a model home. Kip let him talk. He smiled with attention and held a worm and corrected a child softly and helped a woman get past a small fear of small cold things, and when the man with the shoes said the words Bio-Opportunity with three hyphens, Aunt Beryl dropped a cake on the table with the force of a sermon and the syllables fell apart and rotted on the grass in a way that made three teenagers laugh into their sleeves. CHOICES fluttered closer as if unwilling to miss an opening, and Kip felt the sedative of forgetting walk past them in sensible shoes and try to shake his hand. He turned his palm at the last moment and had it shake a clod of compost instead, and the small movement was enough to make the council liaison’s smile fall off like a button that had been hanging on by habit.

They found the bin’s problem without making a scene because the rats had experience with avoiding hysteria in public. Knife leapt light onto Maureen’s table and slapped the hinge of the lid with both paws as if hitting a tambourine, and Tansy took the hint and slid a gloved hand under the rim and held it there long enough for the smell to make a new shape that could be named. Alan stepped in with his best look that said I am a man you do not want to argue with about regulations no matter who you are, and he said, loud enough to make the CHOICES clipboard flinch, “This is not organic. This is not fit for soil. This is a solvent with a label that has had a label peeled off it, which any fool knows leaves the sticky behind, and I know my stickies. Who brought this into a garden?”

There is the kind of silence that is an absence, and then there is the kind that is a presence that has put a heavy thing on a table and dares you to say you didn’t see it. The developer’s mouth went into a shape that wanted to be a circle and became a line, and the council man discovered that squinting would not make the old brand name on the bottle’s shoulder un-ghost: MISTRAL 90 in letters that thought they were clean. The CHOICES woman put her clipboard against her chest like a shield and began to say something about intervening when the community begins to hallucinate hazards that are outside its capacity to process, and the Anchor’s pin burned his cuff like breath. Rot-Right pressed its nose against the inside of his teeth like a bored dog who has been very good and sees a ball. Kip breathed dirt into his own throat on purpose and let it scratch.

He did not make a speech about sabotage. He didn’t need the day to break into sides when it had only just learned to be a circle. He said instead, “Sometimes people get confused about what removes and what returns. Sometimes it is an accident and sometimes it is a man in a suit with an old grudge against anything that makes him feel like he has to learn a new word. We don’t have to work out which today.” He took the bottle, which felt offended in his hand, and he set it aside without pomp and asked Maureen to bring the vinegar and the bicarb and the bucket that had been christened for emergencies. He brought the children forward like firefighters with small hands and gave them small jobs with grand titles and kept them talking about their favorite smells while the stinging kind tried to tell their noses a different story and was drowned in domestic charisma. The developer attempted to look helpful and held a funnel, which was probably the first useful thing he had done in months that did not involve a spreadsheet.

After they had poured and scrubbed and apologized to the worms for the noise, Maureen took off her hat to scratch and revealed hair like the inside of a tree, and without ceremony she reached down to the edge of the main heap and brought up a stone the size of a loaf of bread that did not look like it had been there yesterday. It had the particular weight of stone carried, a heat under its cool, and its color was the sound of sleep. She didn’t seem surprised by it, and Kip did not need her to be. The You Yang aunties had a habit of sending what was necessary when it was time to stop pretending that volunteers can do everything with cheerful signage. The auntie had signed her work in the curve of the rock, a shallow arc that made your wrist relax when you held it, and in the rounded place on one side where you could set your palm and feel the slow breathing that only hills permit themselves when nobody is watching.

“That goes under,” Maureen said, with the authority of someone who had been told what to do by people with a view of the bay and had no intention of arguing. “It will keep the heat from getting silly. It will remind us that we are not the first to play with rot and that we will not be the last. No stickers. No hashtags. Just gratitude.” Kip set the stone at the base of the new heap like a keel, and when his fingers left it, he felt the whole pile sit down comfortably, like a person taking their shoes off at the end of a shift, and he breathed with it and took a little of its calm into a pocket in his chest that had been yawning.

The council man had more courage once the moment had passed its edge and become administratively solvable. He promised to look into procurement policies with a seriousness that made him look younger, and he took Maureen’s pamphlet about what plants liked coffee and which ones preferred eggshells and said he would give it to his mother. The developer did a thing with his face that was intended to demonstrate magnanimity, and when Aunt Beryl offered him cake he said yes as if accepting charity he was above and then blushed when he realized he had given himself away. CHOICES dissolved into the crowd like sugar in tea and left behind a sweetness that made some people forget to be angry and others remember just in time. Mrs Ipswich reached down and stole a crumb in a way that made three small boys gasp and then giggle and then look around to see if they were supposed to pretend they had not seen a rat be graceful.

The best thing happened in the corner where the little tubs of finished compost sat like treasure in a museum. Children without prompting began to rub small smears on each other’s wrists as if it were a festival with a ritual they had invented and not told adults about, and they gave each other roles in whispers that sounded very important. They decided that the dirt smell could be a shield against forgetting, and they named themselves Keepers of Filth with the kind of pride that makes a child impervious to mockery for a week. Kip did not interfere with their liturgy; he knew the difference between a game and a spell, and sometimes the game is better at sticking. He laughed deep in his ribs where laughter oils a hinge, and Rot-Right turned over content and took a nap with one ear open.

Later, when the musician boys had finished their love song to compost and tried to segue to an unrelated ballad about a girl named Cass, and For The Love Of Worms had shouted into her hat that the raffle would happen in five minutes and that you could not put down two dollars and call yourself a worm farmer, and the sun slanted itself to make the You Yangs look like guarding dogs, Kip walked over to the fish and chip place at the corner and asked, in the language of men with aprons and burns, whether the trimmings from tonight’s prep could be put into a black bucket and left by a certain grate for a rat queen with ethics. The man behind the counter had the face of someone who had known a lot of secret handshakes between oil and spice and who enjoyed complicated arrangements if they made something taste better. He agreed without making it dramatic, but he did ask if there would be anything in it for him, and Kip offered a discount on guilt that night and a bag of soil in a fortnight that would make his backyard coriander show off. They shook on it with a fishy palm and a hand that smelled like rosemary, and both men went away believing themselves clever.

Kip could have gone home then, the sort of home you make when your body knows how to curl itself under tea-tree and not be noticed by anyone with bad ideas. He didn’t, because he had promised himself after the tunnel to take certain kinds of tiredness to water and certain kinds to stone. He followed the bay’s edge until the promenade gave up and turned into ordinary path and then into bald honest earth, and he took the long way around so that he could feel the breath under him change at the places where old piers once had their feet. Tansy fell into step because he had been walking long enough for her to get bored of cleaning cake knives and because she liked the way people made way for her without knowing they were doing it. She had the hoodie up and her hands in the pocket and had not noticed that she had kept her high-vis on, which made her look like an occupational health and safety fairy on unpaid overtime.

“You were good,” she said, which for her meant she had been proud and had had to not smile where Maureen could see and think she was weak. “You didn’t try to fix anyone’s soul. You just let them put dirt up their nose and gave it a name that made them not hate themselves. I approve. You smell less like wrong now.”

“I had help,” he said, meaning stone and iron and rats and aunties, and also that thing inside him that had sat down like a dog with manners. “I wanted to call it a king again and then I remembered that kings are just men who have avoided being pushed in the mud, and I am not in the mood to flatter men today. The Anchor gave me a pin like a threat. It helps. Also the ring is itchy, which is good. It makes me remember that I am stupid.”

“That’s why some people get tattoos,” she said. “So they keep the moment of pain where they can read it instead of letting it fade into muscle memory. I’m glad you put plastic on it too. The bracelet says you know the world likes to trick you into making the same joke twice in front of people who will never forgive you for it.”

“It does say that in Comic Sans,” he agreed solemnly, and they stood at the end of Cunningham Pier to watch a little girl swing her legs and repeat in a small private chant the names she had given herself and her friends, Keepers of Filth, Keepers of Filth, until the words skinned themselves of their obvious meanings and became a spell that would keep her from ever buying a bottle of something that claimed to make things go away without cost. Their city moved around them with the cheap grace of a man in a suit trying very hard not to trip on a step and pulling it off and then checking to see who had seen him not fall.

They went up to the You Yangs the following afternoon because the Anchor had sent a text that consisted of a hill emoji and a spanner and a skull, which in auntie talk meant bring your wrench and your common sense and be prepared to be told you were a clown. Alan drove because he had a ute and because his idea of a good time was bolting a problem to a solution with the wrong tool and then convincing both that they had chosen each other. Jet came with a notebook because her teacher had once told her that field notes were for grown-ups and she had never forgiven that implication. Mrs Ipswich refused a seat on the dashboard and instead rode in the tray with the joy of someone who had discovered that rat balance and a human vehicle made for a fine ride if you didn’t mind the occasional bump that felt like a new idea.

The stone aunties met them by pretending not to be there. They let the city recede, and they brought birds in close, and the air had weight that anyone foolish would call oppressive and anyone sensible would feel in their ankles with gratitude. They did not step out of the rock because that would have made for a spectacle and the aunties did not perform for cousins. They made a particular sound instead, a clack like someone tapping a chain against a fence to call a dog home from the far side of mischief, and Kip stood still so that his skin could hear it and then moved forward with the caution of a man going into a room of women whose photographs stand on mantelpieces he is not in.

They told him what he knew and then they told him what he didn’t. They told him his ring was ugly enough to be useful and the plastic bracelet was a good insult to the right people and that he should not give up that habit. They told him Rot-Right would sulk if ignored and hence should be fed like a cousin who has moved in unexpectedly, which is to say with respect and leftovers, and that if he had to choose between going under alone because a child was drowning and waiting for permission, he should bring the child up and apologize later to his elders for being built like a rescue. They told him not to give his new job to the council without ensuring that whoever took it had a grandmother who had dirt under her nails at least once. They told him there would be more of the solvent kind because someone had money for it and an idea of what clarity should smell like, and that the name of the man might begin with a letter that likes to lean.

Alan wandered off and found a bolt that didn’t belong to the hill and looked at it the way men looked at old photographs of themselves, and Jet wrote down the fact that when you sit on a particular rock, it presses the ache in your back into a shape that feels like a hand and that this is not terrifying if you have been loved before. Tansy listened with her hood up and knew that half the boys she had kissed would not have heard any of it and felt suddenly less lonely for it. Mrs Ipswich ran up and down a crack with the look of a creature inspecting property, considered the possibility of a holiday home in granite, and decided her people preferred bins with lids large enough to declare an ideology.

When they came down, the bay’s color had changed three times while they had been held, and Kip could feel the city’s appetite for story pushing at him like a friend with an elbow. He did not go into a drain. He went to the fishmonger with his bucket that had acquired a designation it did not know it had desired, and he accepted trimmings with the respect owed to parts that had once been part of someone’s supper in the making. He walked along the safe corridor after dark and set the bucket down like an offering, and Mrs Ipswich turned up with a committee and said a blessing in a language that had been invented that day and would be forgotten in the morning except by those who keep minutes where the feet go.

Rot-Right stood at his shoulder and sniffed and made polite eyes at the fish and then looked at him to make sure, because rules are like leashes, and you can love the hand that holds them or hate it. He pressed his hand to the grate and let the iron ring bruise him a little to give the yes weight. He said, not aloud, not whispered, just breathed the idea so that it fogged and cleared on its own, we feed, not frenzy. The taste of it came back as agreed, and he carried that agreement all the way up through his arm into the bed he made of ordinary and slept like a man who had done a day’s work and would do another. He dreamed, inevitably, of worms with badges, of rats in hi-vis, of children reminding their parents to put orange peels in a bucket, and of a stone laughing so low that no one could be offended, only steadied, which is the kind of laugh that keeps a city together when it would prefer to get new shoes and run away.

The next week taught him that every ritual becomes a rota, which is how you know it is working and also how you know it will wear people down if you do not let it be funny. He put reminders in his phone with emojis he had to pretend to himself he did not find adorable; he let Alan bully a foreman into installing a proper grate on the west side by using the words liability exposure like a weapon; he took three calls from the council man who now referred to himself as a champion of urban composting in emails and only smiled a little with his teeth. He walked past the bath most mornings and touched the handrail with two fingers because the tiles liked that, and he could feel the different kind of clean that comes when someone has kept a promise to not remove but return. He held his iron ring when CHOICES left a flyer at Aunt Beryl’s declaring that the council offered free consultations for people who found themselves obsessed with drains beyond a healthy concern, and he did not ring and he did not throw it away; he put it in the drawer with the batteries so that the next time he needed to power something, he would take out the flyer and laugh like a person who knows exactly where his weaknesses are because he has named them.

He and Tansy went under with Alan and Jet and sometimes Maureen and occasionally one of the older men from the garden who had been convinced that the drains were a place like a shed, with rules and handy shelves, and they took paint in buckets and wrote in places only rain could read, and the rain read and it did not forget. They scrubbed where the solvent kind sulked and made themselves a chore list that would have been depressing if it had not been broken into parts named after cakes. They learned the names of new rats because Mrs Ipswich had decided that municipal jobs came with performance reviews and gossip, and that if you wanted to move your family into a good pipe, you had to show you could take a joke about the time you ate an entire packet of jelly snakes and did not sleep for three days.

On the day he was due to talk to a room full of men who liked ties and counted their worth in carparks about the joys of rot, Kip put his hat on and then took it off and put his iron-and-plastic wrist between his teeth for a second the way people do to make themselves threaten to cry and then not. He thought about bringing the stone auntie to the meeting and laughed out loud at the picture of himself walking in with a boulder under his arm and breaking a shoe. He took his bucket of good dirt and his jar of live worms and the honest smell that makes suits pretend they cannot smell anything because they have to pretend they are above their noses, and he went to speak not as a boy apologizing for being clever but as a citizen inviting other citizens to put their hands in a future that would feed them. He did not plan his jokes because planning ruins them; he planned his silences and his spoon, and he decided that if anyone said Bio-Opportunity again, he would hand them a worm with the solemnity usually reserved for godchildren, and then he would stop because there are rules, and also because Aunt Beryl had promised to hex his ears if he refused to accept that sometimes charm is cruel when applied correctly.

The minute before he opened his mouth, he felt a rich current of sour-with-purpose slide along his ribs and nest in the hollow where his breath sits. Rot-Right had woken up for a speech. Kip did not bat it away or invite it to share the microphone. He sat it in the front row of his mind and told it to take notes, and when the men with ties laughed the second time, he let himself believe that they could learn something that would make the drains not a secret but a pride, and that belief felt like heat slipping into a cold room without being able to say its name.

He did not open with a joke, though his mouth could have done it with his eyes closed and his hands occupied with worms. He opened with work, which is the safer cousin of charm. He tipped a small ribbon of coffee grounds into a clear box and then a layer of shredded paper that had once been council pamphlets and then a confetti of lettuce that had gone from crisp to sorry, and he did it like someone teaching sleep to a baby: unhurried, confident, ordinary magic that doesn’t need clapping. He let his voice be warm without projecting, because power that doesn’t strain often does more damage and more good, and he said the same small true thing three times in three ways so it could fit into different ears. Return is not rot being disgusting; return is gratitude in slow motion. Worms are stomachs and mouths and also citizens with a job to do. If you put in what they like, they will make you something you can run your hands through without thinking about what it used to be and without apologizing to anyone in your head.

They laughed first at each other, which is always a better sign than laughing at you. The man with the polish on his shoes let it be known that he could do humility by bending over and peering into the clear box as if it were a rare painting, and Kip kept his face soft and said something bland about ratios that did two jobs: it let the man talk to his own discomfort about dirt, and it reminded everyone else that there was a way to be smug about banana peels if you needed to be. A woman with neat hair and a badge that said Community Partnerships put her palm over the tub of finished compost like a fortune-teller and asked what she was supposed to see, and Kip put a handful into her hand without warning her properly because the best way to cut the ribbon on a new idea is to put it where skin is, and when she smiled despite herself, he felt Rot-Right stretch under his ribs like a dog who has been told it is allowed on the couch this once.

The developer stood with his body turned half towards the sea and half towards the crowd, as if he were on the verge of introducing them to each other and hoping not to be blamed if they didn’t get along. He talked about systems. He said the word circular so many times it rolled off his tongue and became a wheel and tried to crush nuance under it, and when he said Bio-Opportunity Kip heard Aunt Beryl laugh in his memory and saw, out of the corner of his eye, Tansy take the measure of the man with one glance and shelf him under people who would refuse to use a mug twice if it had washed and dried between. The council liaison stood inside his own smile like a man wearing a wetsuit one size too small, and CHOICES drifted like a cool current in a room that had no water, the woman with the clipboard keeping just far enough away to not interact and close enough to be the shadow of a good idea.

He gave them a small trick because you have to feed audiences something sweet before you hand them vegetables. He showed them how to use a spoon to move worms gently without making themselves feel like murderers. He told the story of a boy who had brought his worm farm to school and watched with astonishment as the boy everyone thought was cruel stood for fourteen minutes without swatting a single fly and then went home and asked his mother if they could learn to make less. He did not say the boy was him; he put the boy into the room and let the men with ties wear him for a moment without liking how it fit, and he made them laugh at their own seriousness. When they laughed the second time, he let it be his invitation to say two things that might have sounded scolding if they hadn’t been wrapped in dirt that smelled like cake: don’t put citrus peels in until the system is older; don’t call a thing clean because you can’t smell it.

When the questions came, they came with the particular tilt of heads that says we want your expertise inside our spreadsheet without you in the meeting where we allocate funds. How do you scale? Who holds risk? What will you do when the community loses interest? He answered like a person who had known what a ledger was since he could count and had always refused to let it decide whether a story was worth telling. You scale by multiplying small good habits and then doing what is necessary to make sure they are not punished. You hold risk the way you hold a jar full of sourdough starter: carefully, with a towel under in case of overflow, with respect for the exponential. Communities lose interest when they are not allowed to be funny; keep the humor in and the carrots tend themselves. Rot-Right paced once up and back under his heart as he said it, and he put his thumb against the iron and the plastic and the pin to keep the pacing from turning into a dash.

Afterwards, when the worm-handling had devolved into a sort of low-key sacrament and Maureen had sold so many transparent boxes that she had started warning people against themselves, the developer made his move. He invited Kip to say soil with him in a little knot of men who kept looking over their shoulders at the bay like singled people at a wedding considering leaving early. He spoke about pilot programs and deliverables and thought he was doing Kip a favor by letting him see the engine room. Kip listened as if the words were rain and he was under a properly maintained verandah. He said thank you in the tone that means I understand that we have different jobs and mine isn’t to be your conscience or your free marketing, and he smiled with his teeth under his lips, which is the way to smile when you want to remind a man that you have canine molars too and you just choose, most days, not to bite.

CHOICES came in sideways, the clipboard held like a shield with rounded corners. She didn’t introduce herself by any name that would stick; she introduced herself by service, which is a way of saying hello without being held to it later. We can help, she said without moving her mouth much, when the community begins to report… distortions. We have procedures. We can keep the brand clean. The word brand turned into a piece of plastic in Kip’s mouth that his tongue could not push to the side, and for a moment he wanted to spit with a shocking lack of manners and see if anyone tried to ticket him. He didn’t. He put his hand into the tub of compost again and then touched his own wrist where the skin was thinner and made dirt into a bracelet to match the LiveStrong and the iron. I don’t want clean, he said with unembarrassed softness. I want honest. If you take away the complications I can work with, you leave me with a flat surface and a reflection. He thought she might break; she smiled instead and said, we are always here if you become overwhelmed by context, and the quiet threat of that sentence sat like a moth in his mouth until he breathed it out while bending to talk to a five-year-old about how worms cannot eat Lego.

When it was done, when the teenagers had stopped playing long enough to find dignity in how much they had sweated and the council man had taken his mother’s pamphlet and put it in his pocket like contraband because leaving it in his hand would have made it less likely to be read, he took his bucket and his hands and walked the perimeter to make sure everyone was leaving with ideas that weren’t going to make Maureen swear later. Rot-Right hummed like a refrigerator does—a constant small presence that becomes alarming only when it stops—and when the hum shifted once to a higher pitch, he gave his neck a little twist and saw, the way you see water move under a breeze you didn’t feel, the bin under the peppercorn where the solvent man had tried to make an idea. He found himself grateful that insult had been defeated in daylight and by vinegar. It suggested that the next move would be after dark and harder and that he should make sure his spectacles were clean, which is what Aunt Beryl calls the kind of thinking you put on when the obvious lies down.

He did not get to sit with that thought long enough to box it and label it for later because the sky did something deliberate. The bay is unashamed of weather; it lets its moods show. The breeze came up with fewer jokes in it. The light found a color it hadn’t been wearing. On the fringe of the gardens, the peppercorn trees rubbed their scent together like anxious people warming their hands, and someone said in the comfortable tone of a man who has always distrusted forecasts and is now delighted to be a prophet, that’ll be a storm then. Kip looked south and saw the line of dark coming like a teacher back to school after a strike, and he turned to the table nearest him and began the sort of sensible abrupt packing that saves cake and headphones and also pride.

It was not a storm that came to tidy. It was one that came to find where your house had been built poorly and tell everyone. The first drops hit the skin like a warning and then forgot themselves and became a slap; the smell on the air folded lemon in with wet wool. Maureen covered her worm tubs with practiced hands and called to two boys who had not yet learned to be embarrassed about sprinting to put the signs away, and the council man stood for a moment with his tie doing a small dance and then took it off with a look of a man who had been waiting years for the moment when he would tell his tie to behave and it would not. Tansy put Jet into a jacket that would have kept a seal pup smug and grabbed the cake box as if it were a small child which, in a town like this, it nearly was. Kip lifted the tub of finished compost like a baby and held onto his hat with the other hand and laughed because the world had decided to be interesting at an inconvenient time and there is a kink in him that loves that.

He was halfway to the shed when the first roar came up from the stormwater that belied the polite name. It said, I have been waiting in pipes and I will now speak, and people who have never listened to drains before heard it and looked towards the low places where footpaths become small creeks and then big ones. He thought of the writing they had put in places only rain could read, the letters that told water the old paths and asked it to take them. He put the tub down and put his hands on the nearest grate the way a person puts their palms on a friend’s shoulders when they want to talk to them seriously, and he sent his voice down into the rush with the shapes that make directions without sounding like commands. The iron ring heated with friction he wasn’t making with motion, and the pin the Anchor had set in his cuff burned a line against his kitchen-self until he wanted to wrestle it off and throw it in the bay and then go down after it and apologize.

Rot-Right woke fully, without yawning, and put its weight into the corners of him like a person bracing furniture before a door when someone knocks too hard. It wanted to take taste from what was coming up, and he did not forbid that, he redirected it the way you give a child a carrot when they ask for sugar. Not fear, he told it, not breath. Take the swill. Take the kitchen. Leave the ankles. It heard him because the iron made his voice sit heavy enough for it to take it seriously. Across the lawn, Alan had seen the same change and was already moving with the conviction that turns men into warnings; he ended up at the west side, where the weak bracket had finally given up on its responsibilities. He had the new one in his hand, not because he had expected exactly this moment, but because people like Alan carry the solution to two likely problems at all times and a willingness to lie about whether they knew they’d need it.

The first surge over the curb brings glamour to places that don’t often get it, and children briefly make sounds that make mothers draw in breath without scolding, but the second will take a foot if it can. The bath at Eastern Beach obeyed its own logic and slopped at the edges like a big bowl carrying too much soup. Una was there without being seen to arrive, her tattoos ready for a fight and her whistle in the key of attention cuts through rain, and she put rope in hands before the hands knew they wanted it. A line formed right of nothing and wrong became a plan, and people held each other as if holding were a job. Kip did not go to the bath; he went under. It would have been a story to say he forgot to bring anyone. He didn’t. He lifted his hand to come and then dropped it because Tansy was shoving Jet into a safer place and Aunt Beryl was tying down a tent with a rope and Alan had his bracket and Maureen was busy seducing worms into staying home. He said out loud to the storm the two words that make the difference between arrogance and practice, coming back, and then he went down.

The drain had the voice of a thing happy to be what it was; under a storm, that voice can drown the bright bit of you if you haven’t eaten enough, and Kip had, that day, in cake and praise and urgency. The rain read the letters they had painted the week before with a solemnity that made him want to hug Jet for naming it the silliest thing at the time, and the water took the old path where they had asked it to, which is to say that what had been a trick became a rule for a little while and that was enough. He made his light small so he wouldn’t see everything and put his palm on the tunnel wall and let his breath match the rush and then the long, and when the tug came at his ankles that said you could go now and be a story of someone we say an elegant thing about, he pressed the iron to his teeth and concentrated on terrible small truths like the names of his toes and the fact that he had left the kettle on a thousand times and never burned the house and that Aunt Beryl had once let a cake fall and had sworn at it with affection.

The smell that came wasn’t Rot’s. It was the other one, the removal one, and it came bright, clean, false, as if someone had put a lemon in their mouth and told you they had tasted the sea. It came with the sound a hospital makes at two in the morning when everything is fine and then you think about it and nothing is fine. It didn’t want to eat; it wanted to dissolve. It wanted to make the boundaries go away so that nothing had to be counted and no one had to look at the smear and say I did that. It smelled like the word pristine when it has been put on a brochure with a picture of water that has forgotten it is made of time. Kip felt Rot-Right flinch, not because it was afraid, but because it knew an insult when it met one. He pulled it back by the scruff in his mind and set it to the edges as if this were a pastry that needed to stop its leak. The solvent smell slid past his nose and tried to hide inside his sense of relief and he thought, with uncharacteristic clarity, no, you are not a kindness, and named it for himself in the privacy of his head: Away.

It didn’t like that. It did not live in names; it lived in the spaces between words where responsibility fades out because everyone is tired. It poured itself towards him with the intent of a hand with a cloth and he held up his iron like it could be more than metaphor and it was, for the length of a breath, enough. It hissed against the ring as if you could make a sound with an idea when you don’t have teeth, and he made himself heavy as stone. He thought of the aunties who had put a rock in the worm pile and how the whole coil of heat there had sat down like sense finally heard, and he made that weight inside himself on purpose in a way he had never had to do before so that he would not become a light thing that can be carried off.

The rain found his back and made him into slope and culvert, and if he had not heard Alan’s particular cursing from the mouth of the drain a long way off he might have let the arms of the water carry him three inches and then six and then he would have had to be clever in a way that is not compatible with keeping your own breath. He fixed his feet. He made his light a little bigger not for himself but for the thing that wanted to see where it could be useful and he said, not to Rot-Right and not to Away and not to the storm but to the brick and the old flow and the smell of tallow that the place had not yet given up, remember your job. The brick did, because brick is reliable when you don’t ask it to do more than hold. The old flow remembered the river. The tallow remembered fat that had fed people who had cried when they thought about being dammed, and that sadness, being honest, made the remove-idea jump back as if it had put a hand on something hot by mistake.

He found the smear that had not dissolved the week before because it had not been asked to; it glowed in his small light with the satisfaction of a stain that has been given attention and thinks it means it will be kept. He put his hand very near it without touching because there are ways to be intimate with horror that do not involve bodily fluids, and he pushed the thought at it that Aunt Beryl has taught him to use when a person shows up with a casserole that is mostly guilt and wants to be thanked. Not here. We are busy. Take your story somewhere else. It did not go because he had told it so; it went because the rain reading their letters made the tunnel into a throat that wasn’t interested in being burned and chose a different gulp.

When he came up, the world had more edges in it. The air made needles of itself against his cheeks and he laughed, not out of bravery but as if he had almost fallen off a bike and for a second had thought of the blood and then had not bled and your body insists on celebrating the absence. Una was a shape in the slanting rain, her strong hands holding rope, the rope holding people, the people holding each other. Tansy stood with her hoodie stuck to her skull like kelp and her eyes narrow and her mouth old and kind and mean, which is to say she was doing the work of being clever while tired. Jet had a whistle and was not using it, which is proof that children can be saints when their hands are full. Alan stood with one knee in a puddle and a bracket installed so cleanly that an inspector would have wept, and he had the particular rigor mortis of men who have been right at the exact right time and are now ridiculous about it.

The meltdown after a storm is always a little stupid. Everyone wants to tell their small version of heroism to the nearest person with a face and the people with faces don’t want to hear it yet. They stood under a bit of tin that had not been asked to shelter more than one person at once for twenty years and shared heat like mammals. Aunt Beryl took a rollcall without pretending she wasn’t doing it and then handed out cake from the box she had saved like a contraband rosary, and because humans are very easily led, the act of putting something sweet into a wet mouth convicted them of survival and told their bodies to calm down. The council man looked at his hands as if they had done something he had not budgeted for and then shook his head once and went to get more rope because he had learned something he didn’t know where to put and the easiest place was back into his hands, and CHOICES stood with the kind of posture that says we can help anyone who will sign this form in the rain.

Kip found he was shivering not because cold but because everything had put away its edges too quickly and his body had nowhere to put the spare. He put his iron against his face and let it be colder than he was, and when he went to find Aunt Beryl because he needed the kind of telling off that feels like you are being wrapped in a towel, he walked into the Anchor instead and thought, briefly and idiotically, that perhaps he had become her, because there is a moment when you meet your anchor and your shape relaxes around it with the inevitability of a bag of flour finding the shape of its jar. She stood with rain-line hair and needles sticking out of a ball of knitting like weaponry and eyes like safe places, and she did not make a joke about how he smelled, though she could have. She nodded once and put a wet hand on his wet cheek and said, which is to say pronounced, because some words are court orders in their softness, that will come again not because you failed but because it is made of people. He wanted to argue for the luxury of blame and could not because she did not leave space for indignity.

He told her about Away without using the name he had thought in his head, because sometimes names work two ways and he had no reason to send a calling card. He told her about the hiss at the iron and the way it had slid into his sense of relief like a thief in a convenience store pretending to be staff. She frowned with satisfaction because being right is also a job when you are old and she had been hoping he would see it. The aunties said don’t name that one yet, she said as if it had been said on a piece of wind and lodged in her shawl. Make a box and write do not open until you have a broom big enough to hit it with. In the meantime, do what you have been doing, which is tie rules to everything that will accept a knot. Teach your dog to sit in rooms full of meat without embarrassing you. Feed it. Don’t let it eat people’s small shocks. And when the men with solvent come with clipboards, send them to me. I have a tone of voice that makes a foreman lie down with a headache.

He did as he was told not because he is obedient generally but because he has chosen his queens with care. The storm ran out of drama and sat down, and the light did that thing the bay’s light does after it has been showing off, where it settles into the work of making shape and line visible. They walked home without stories, which is one of the best ways to walk in a town like this; it leaves the air uncluttered for the next thing. He slept hard and not sensible, too tired to be political with his own dreams, and woke with the taste of metal and rosemary in his mouth, which he decided to take as a benediction in Aunt Beryl’s dialect.

Jet’s school carnival landed in the middle of the week like a boisterous aunt sitting on an arm of the couch not meant to hold a person. Kip went because he liked the way school events turned the day into a festival and because Jet had said, casually in a tone carefully oiled to not beg, that it would be good if someone who could pull a girl out of a water with laughter stood near the shallow end. He put on a big shirt that made him look like an uninteresting adult and wore his iron like it was jewelry because sometimes you need to train the part of you that wants to vanish into behaving like a person. It wasn’t magical, the day; it was ordinary in a way that heals. He bought a sausage in bread from a father who had not wanted to grill and had done it anyway because masculinity is a chore, and he put sunscreen on a child who was not his, and he clapped for learners who came last and did not cry, and he felt Rot-Right sit and watch and obey the rule about children because rules are habits if you feed them.

He did one small stupid thing because he is not a saint. A man in sunglasses with a voice that had been taught by talk radio said something about the smell at the shallow end in a tone like a suggestion of court and then laughed when his friend flinched at the taste of pre-boiled water, and Kip, who has empathy in muscle but not always perfect impulse control, flicked the air by the man’s ear with a finger until the smell of dirt crept into his nostril and made him smile against his will. The man laughed wrong and then right, and it was petty and it was not noble, and there are few pleasures so clean. Tansy saw him do it and waited until after to kick his ankle, not to hurt but to mark. He nodded and said sorry you’re right out loud in front of the kiosk because there are some apologies that should be witnessed so they can’t be retracted later in memory, and she patted his shoulder roughly as if shoving him into his better self.

The solvent men did not rest, and neither did the part of the city that aligns itself with clean lines without context. The day after the storm, a boy in a high-vis vest who had the look of someone who had been told good news and then discovered the fine print found a box left under the west bridge with a label that had had a label peeled off. Alan opened it with the care you give a bomb or a wedding invitation, depending on your temperament, and found six bottles with translucent liquid that smelled of virtue and hospital floors. There was no official logo, but the glass bore the ghost of an old brand, and the lid had a scratch shaped like an L, which might have been nothing and might have been the letter that likes to lean. Kip took one in his hand and his stomach clenched like you have when you see a dog going to run across a busy road and you are too far away to make a difference, and he looked at the boy who had found it and saw in him that terrible thing cities do to young men where they become proud of their proximity to danger. He took the pride away gently by putting trouble in his own pocket and replacing it with a job that had a title that sounded important: liaison.

It is satisfying to discover that your enemy has a logo. It makes you believe in the shape of the fight. Kip did not give himself this. He put the bottle in Aunt Beryl’s kitchen because kitchens can transfigure villains into ingredients when you are careful, and he stood there with his hands empty like someone demonstrating contrition to a god he has chosen and said, we need to know how it works before it isn’t allowed to. Aunt Beryl, who had in her time put lye and vinegar within an inch of each other and taught them to behave or be separated indefinitely, sniffed at the top and pinched her face in a way that had once made men in aprons leave knives on benches. She poured a drop—not into the sink, which would have been a conversation with a drain that did not need more gossip, but onto a plate that had once been a roof tile and had been kept for occasions where you wouldn’t be sad if you melted your crockery. The drop sat on the tile and made a noise so soft you only heard it if you liked secrets, and then it did what it was built for, which is take away, and it took away the memory of what had been on the tile before and left behind a scratch.

They learned its rules the way you learn the rules of a sad dog you are determined to love because he is family. It did not eat fat properly; it spread it thinner, like shame. It did not like salt unless given sweetness first. It made paper look like it could not possibly have held words. It turned certain plastics lively in a way that made Tansy swear and put all the Easter tubs on top of the fridge to be dealt with when the council had made up its mind to buy a fire. It did not understand how to be kind about flesh; it could be persuaded to leave alone what had learned to be skin at the expense of other possibilities, but it required loud talk and iron and the steady hand of someone who could put their faith in the fact of edges. You could teach it, in small. You could not trust it in distance.

They sat with the You Yang aunties again without needing to drive, which is to say the aunties came down into the air and the feel of granite settled into the day like a smell you associate with someone you love. Stone doesn’t talk about chemicals; it talks about what they want to do. The aunties said, as if remarking on weather in a tone that was still a warning, that the one that removes will try to become a law. It will try to persuade men who have never opened a jar of preserves in their lives that they have always wanted air they don’t have to breathe. It will wear words like clear and crisp and pure, and people will nod because they are tired of being animals. They said you cannot fight a slogan with three paragraphs. You have to give a different word to the same feeling and make it stick when the body is under strain. They said you name it Away in your own head and you call what you love Near out loud until children repeat it in playgrounds and it becomes rude to say anything else.

He named the near things. He named them in small places where men with neat hair could not ask for a copy of the minutes. He told Jet that when she swam she was putting her body into Near and that if she felt a sleek come to roll under her and make her think she wanted to stand on a tile and leave, she should call that a trick and not a wish. He told Mrs Ipswich that the corridor of pipe that ran from Maureen’s worm fairyland to the river was Near and that if she met anything there that made her whiskers stiffen like she wanted to sneeze, she should slap its idea of itself and make a scandal, because scandal is Near’s way of keeping people honest. He told Tansy that his mouth was Near when she kissed him, which he said as a joke and then wasn’t, and she thumped his shoulder without hitting his iron and said don’t flirt with me when I’m on shift because I will either ignore you or marry you out of spite.

A week after worm day, the developer held a walk-through along the water with men and women who say phrases like activation and place-making without being ashamed that anyone can hear them. He brought his son, which is always the most dangerous kind of camouflage because sons will not do the decent thing and stand where their fathers put them; they go to the places where the smell is most interesting. Kip was not invited but he is nearly impossible to uninvite from his own city, and he took a clipboard from CHOICES without asking because it is harder for people to make you leave if you look like you belong to the bureaucracy. He walked three steps behind the group and put his ear down every now and then to listen to a bolt or a bracket so Alan would feel included, and when the son made his inevitable move towards the lip of a drain that was trying to have a conversation with the storm that had left, Kip met him halfway with the silly hat and said come look at a rat corridor instead, you’ll see something better than a dead thing.

It was Mrs Ipswich’s time to make trouble elegant. She had stationed her younger girls along the corridor with a sense of theatre and a sign in chalk that said RATS ONLY and then smaller underneath you can watch if you don’t touch and then smaller underneath with a drawing of a hand with a red cross through it because sometimes you have to be patronising. The boy put his face against the grate the way children put their faces against windows, and the rats obligingly did rat things that make children honest, like washing their hands with their own little paws vigorously enough that anyone prejudiced against them is forced to admit they are not beholden to stereotypes. The boy laughed with the sound of a family’s money falling off his shoulders for half a minute, and the developer’s face did an unreadable thing and then settled into something we might kindly call surprise. CHOICES drifted forward with a pamphlet that promised to remove any unpleasant images from your child’s long-term memory for a small fee, and the son said without irony, as if he had spent his life rehearsing to be useful, I want to remember this, and Kip felt savage affection for him the way you feel for a kitten that has accidentally clawed the face of a man who needed it.

The solvent men made their mistake that evening, which is to say they made their inevitability early and this is useful for stories. They poured their clean into a place they thought no one would see—an underpass near the old woolstores where the air had acquired a memory of bodies and where the walls were layered with graffiti that had been clever and then been painted over by the city and then pressed back under in newer colours that had not yet learned to hold. It should have gone away, the paint, under solvent’s hand; that is the promise removal makes. It did not, because the people who had made the jokes in colour had also made them in shape, and rain had read them and water remembers when asked. What the solvent did was pull the pigment into a wetness, and then because it was too proud to trickle, it slid and pooled and made a slick that reflected faces in a way that made you believe you would forget yours and then discover you had not.

They went with brooms and buckets and vinegar again because this is a city that knows how to repeat the useful processes until someone builds a ritual out of them. They went with a stone from the aunties because the You Yangs like to put their weight where it will be felt, and they set the stone down where the solvent had made a gleam and told the gleam to be tired. Maureen came with a kid who had been making microscopic friends in a jar since she was four and now had a tray of bacteria that could eat things it shouldn’t have known the names of, and she poured them with reverence and a disgust that was part of her piety. Alan brought a bracket just in case and ended up using it for nothing, which is the purest joy of a prepared man. Jet brought a whistle and this time blew it because she wanted to see if the tone would make the gleam forget itself, and it did, a little, because sound has mass if you aim it right.

Kip did not name the solvent thing aloud. He told it what it could not have—not children, not courage, not bold colours that had been jokes about politicians and hearts and lovemaking on picnic tables—and he fed Rot-Right a diet as carefully curated as an oncologist’s protocol: old fat, coffee, leaves, the honorable end of lettuce. He said Near to everything with edges until he was annoying even to himself, and then he said it again and made it funny so that people could copy it without feeling like they were signing a treaty. The CHOICES woman stood in the half light with a clipboard she did not write on and looked as if she wanted to say we can fix this and then remembered the rule someone had taught her once about not promising what you can’t do in front of press. The council man showed up with a truck and four teenagers in vests and a painter’s mask and said tell me where to stand and did not make a speech about consultation, and Kip turned his face sideways so the man wouldn’t see how much he liked him at that moment because he did not want to add to anyone’s burdens with his own gratitude.

He slept hard after that because people do. He woke in the middle of the night because cats fight at two and three and the city has never liked to do anything privately. He sat up without sitting up and felt under his rib the curious sensation of being sung to by something with no throat. It did not feel like Rot-Right; it didn’t feel like Away; it felt like water laughed sideways through a pipe. He went to the window and saw nothing but the black of weather to come, and then on the sill he saw two marks like lines made by a child who cannot yet be trusted with pen and wall. They were in salt, which is the You Yangs’ handwriting when they can’t be bothered with granite, and the lines were this shape: a plumb bob and a hook.

The aunties were, in their way, interested in his promise not to go under alone. They had sent a counterweight and a way to steal. A plumb is not fancy; it is a string with a weight at the end that points only in one direction. A hook is a hook. He took the message into his pocket and lay down and did not pretend that he would not fail his promise at some point when breath was at stake. He made instead the smaller vow that he would fail it cleanly and tell on himself quickly and wear whatever iron he was given without sulking in front of children. The idea that he couldn’t save everyone had become in the last few weeks less like a spear and more like a spoon; it was still sharp, but he had learned to eat with it.

Morning broke like something made of sugar and starch; it held together because everyone was too tired to poke it before coffee. He was at Aunt Beryl’s before she had five minutes to be offended by his hair, and he cleaned the stove with a cloth no one would miss while she pretended she needed his help and then let him steal a handful of the ends of a cake that had been trimmed to look square for a man who thought geometry could be tasted. The iron itched like thought. The plastic bracelet caught the cuff of his shirt and made him swear in a way that would have offended the man who had invented it in a different decade, and Aunt Beryl looked at his wrist and sniffed again and then kissed her teeth at him like a cat making an opinion. You’re getting good at this, she said as if she meant something else as well, and he considered the interesting possibility of being good at not being special and found himself suspicious of how much he liked it.

He saw the developer again that day because cities are loops and men who want to build have to walk the same rocks as men who want to keep. The man had a small dog with comedic eyebrows that announced his wife had a sense of humor and that he was trying to borrow it. He talked about setbacks as if he were rehearsing for a panel and said the phrase reputational risk with a long enough vowel that Kip could have threaded it on a string. Kip said I am happy to help if help means making a mess in daylight that we then clean up together, and the man looked at him as if he had spoken Latin and then barked with laughter because the dog had farted at exactly the moment when language did not work. It is rude and true that what you need to make citizens out of consumers is often an embarrassing noise and a bag.

The afternoon brought small chores: convincing a butcher to save bones in a separate bin because the rats had opinions about marrow; having an argument with a teenager with a skateboard about whether the gold paint that said you are loved looked better in italics or bold; talking to a woman whose son had decided he wanted to be a plumber because drains are chatty and being decent about her fears of trades; telling Maureen that no, not all coffee shops will give you their grounds if you stare at them hard, you need to smile and promise to mention them on a signboard and then do it twice. He did each thing with the same attention he would have given to saving a child, which is how you make a town that doesn’t resent being lectured at, and every time he wanted to be clever merely for the pleasure of feeling the edges of it he put his fingers under the iron until the itch put him back into a body.

When night laid itself down on the city like a reasonable blanket and people gave themselves permission to be smaller in a room with a door, he took the plumb bob and the hook to the bridge because not doing so would have ached worse than the iron. He did not tell anyone because nobody answers their phone at ten without a question that hurts, and he did not go under alone because he had learned that if you go under alone, you have to keep your first promise every ten seconds like a religious chant and you forget to listen. He texted Alan a photo of the plumb with a spanner emoji and a skull, which was their agreed-upon code for I’m doing a thing and it has bones in it and if I don’t text again in ten minutes you may break things in my defense. Alan responded immediately with a picture of a bolt and a heart and then the letter L in a font that leaned and Kip laughed and went.

It was different in the after of a storm and a near miss. The tunnels held their breath in the way of beasts resting on elbows, and the smell of Away hung thin as if it had been told to go sit in the corner and think about what it had done. He hung the plumb bob from a pipe and didn’t think about the fact that he was loitering in a place that had no use for the word loiter. The string knew what it wanted; it found down like a dog finds the boy it lives with in a crowd. He held the hook in his left hand like a thief. When you steal from water you don’t take, you borrow and put back, and you have to be braver than clever, and he is just enough of both.

The plumb settled over a place that looked like every other place and wasn’t. The air there clicked against his teeth like a battery, and the concrete had a stain shaped not by accident but by design, and the design was a logo he had seen without understanding it, and now he did, and for a fragile, delicious, dangerous moment he felt the joy of patterns collapsing into a picture. The L tilted just so, the scratch on the bottle lid magnified to a graffiti. He put his hook under the seam of thought where the solvent men had pried time open and he lifted like you lift a scab when you know it will bleed and are gross and honest enough to do it anyway, and the panel of space that had been thin turned over like a flap on an Advent calendar, and behind it there was not chocolate.

There was a room. He stood in a tunnel and opened not a door; he tilted a thing one degree and then two and found himself looking through air at a space that had decided to capture itself. It wasn’t big in the way architects think of big; it was large the way a lie is large. It held shelving and boxes and those bottles he would have recognized if he were blind and the smell of clean cut with the smell of old meat like alms, and it held a table with a long scratch in the shape of a letter that leaned, and it held two men doing the thing men do when they have convinced themselves they are above consequence: they were laughing at something that hadn’t happened yet as if their laughter would cause its happening to be harmless. He didn’t think hero; he thought oh for god’s sake, because irritation is often the premier fuel for bravery.

He could have gone back for help and made the story polite. He could have taken a photograph and sent it to Aunt Beryl who would have known the name of the cousin of the man who owns the warehouse and can make permits evaporate with a phone call. He might yet do both. But he had a hook and a plumb and iron on his wrist and a habit of getting into trouble when the door is open just enough for a thin boy to slip through. He lifted the flap of air like a curtain and stepped in.

It smelled like mouthwash and lies. He did not let it tell him his nose was wrong. He saw the men turn as if they had heard a door, and perhaps they had, because honesty changes pressure. He put his hand out, palm open, and said the sentence that makes people reveal what they didn’t plan to, I’m so glad I caught you, and they moved like decent citizens who have been momentarily mistaken for villains, which is to say they tried to hide their hands without looking like they were hiding them. He laughed like a bully’s friend and it put them at ease because men like this don’t expect a boy who smells like drains to be in on a joke. He walked past them and took a bottle off the shelf and put it under his nose and pretended to admire it, and in doing so he put his iron wrist in front of his mouth so that whatever wanted to come in would have to argue with an ugly ring first.

He did not hurt them. He wanted to. He wanted to do the stupid good man thing of crushing hands with a broom handle and saying the word community as if it were a weapon. He didn’t because his job is not to be king of bins with a cudgel; it is to make patterns that hold. He said instead in an unthreatening voice, this isn’t going to work, and he let the hook do the work. He slid it under their pride and pulled, and the room tilted. The shelves did not fall; that would have been dramatic and unhelpful. The smell wavered. The ghost of the label on the bottle he held fluttered like a dollar bill in front of a fan, and the idea that they could do this unseen moved sideways, which is often all a lie needs to stop being able to stand.

They blustered. Of course they did. There are scripts for men like this, written into the city like chalk on old brick. They said the council, they said regulation, they said trial, they said necessary, they said early adopter, they said pilot. He repeated after them as if learning a language and pronounced their words wrong on purpose so that little laughter grew shoots out of his mouth and the room became unsafe for the straight, clean lines a brochure loves. He looked at the scratch on the table and let himself be arrogant one second because sometimes the only way to frustrate a man who leans is to lean harder and not fall, and he put his finger on the scar and said in a voice that should have been someone older’s, you don’t get to call it clean if we have to forget to love it.

He left. He took two bottles because he is a thief when theft is a grace and because evidence is a thing that has to be placed on a table in front of men with ties before they will move their heavy hands. He resealed the room without a verb and stood in the familiar wet throat of the city and wanted very much to sit down and cry because it would have been the simplest thing, and instead he texted Alan the word hooks and then the letter L and then a picture of his own iron because he needed to tell the truth to someone who would not make a theory out of it. Alan wrote back a single sentence that was beautiful because it came from a man whose love letter to bolts had never written him in before: I have a friend in Fire who hates solvents on religious grounds, and Kip laughed out loud in a place rain collects and then pressed his forehead to the wall and did nothing clever for thirty breaths because sometimes that is the only way to not be a story you cannot sustain.

He did bring Aunt Beryl the bottles and she did not kiss him or curse him; she put them in a cupboard that had a lock and then she put a bowl of stew in front of him and made him eat and then drink water before she told him that his face had gotten a little worse and that suited him. He went to the Anchor and she said nothing and then spoke a word that felt like a weight, and it helped, as weights do. He slept with the iron ring above his head like he was the kind of person who would put a child’s teeth under a pillow and not be caught by mice, and he dreamt not of drains or solvents or rats in hi-vis but of a field somewhere not near the sea where worms can live without needing to be heroes and thought, as he woke, that he would need to take a train soon and talk to a farmer who had never thought of Geelong as a place where his work might matter.

Morning came with bagpipes in his phone because the universe does not let jokes rest if they are serviceable, and it was the council man, bright as new rope, saying he had a room and chairs and more men than was strictly necessary and would Kip bring his buckets and his dirt. He put the plumb and the hook in his pocket and kissed Aunt Beryl on the cheek without getting hexed for it and put on his hat and went to be a version of himself that made people think they had had the idea first. Rot-Right made itself tall in him without being proud, which is the only way to be safe and useful at once, and the Anchor’s pin scratched his cuff and told him to stand up straighter, and he thought, not without amusement, that the city had decided he would be a boy with a job whether he liked it or not and that he did, which was the real sorcery.

The room was air-conditioned into forgetfulness and carpeted into a kind of compliance that makes people behave as if their shoes matter when they don’t. The men in ties were there, and two women who had the faces of people always put at the end of the table and never asked first, and a man with a Fire emblem on his chest who looked like the sort of person Alan would call when he needed solvents to regret their life choices. The bottles he had stolen sat on the table under a tea towel, domestic and obscene at once, and the council man’s jaw was set in the way of a man who has decided which side he will be embarrassed on and it will not be the one that smells like lemon without lemons.

He did his dirt trick and made them smell memory instead of theory. He took the tea towel off the bottles and made the room flinch and didn’t apologize for the rudeness of daylight on things that prefer shadow. He said Near when he meant policy and laughed when he needed them to breathe and held up the iron ring when he said the words don’t go down alone. He watched the CHOICES woman in the corner with her pen unmoving and saw, for the first time, not a functionary but a person with a mother who had once told her to be brave and had meant something she had not done for a while. He made his case not as a cape-wearing city saviour but as a boy who would like to be held to account by people who can sign checks and wash up after themselves. The Fire man spoke about how solvents change the air and how the air is a thing you are not allowed to ruin because the rest of us own it, and the council man said a sentence that had the word moratorium in it and looked ashamed of the size of it, and a woman at the end of the table said what if we did something good that makes us look like we meant to all along and it felt like a prayer said correctly on the first try.

When Kip left, he wasn’t sure if he had won anything that could be put in an envelope, but he had the sense of something heavy having been placed on a side that had needed it. He walked out into a day that had the decency to be ordinary, and he felt his ring itch without malice and his plastic bracelet catch on the world in ways that kept him anchored, and he watched a gull steal a chip and decide not to eat it and bring it back to a small boy because the boy had clapped the gull for being clever and the gull had remembered that even thieves are susceptible to praise. He laughed and took that as a good omen because he likes to take as many of those as there are, and then he went to the bridge and sat with his feet on a grate and put his hand down to where Near lives and he hummed, a tune without words, a job without grandeur, a kindness that stinks and is therefore worth more than anything wrapped in cellophane.
